Jackson, the former White House physician with no political experience who ran a campaign based on his close relationship with President Trump, won a Republican runoff election for a House seat in Texas on Tuesday night, effectively stamping his ticket to Congress next year.

title: Send You to the Moon
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  Boom! Stay far back. Lee Higbie and Jeff Chen made a puzzle together, and they have apparently blown their tops.

title: Trumps Falsehoods on Police Shootings, Biden, Coronavirus and China
description: In a rambling, campaign-style appearance in the Rose Garden at the White House and in an interview with CBS News on Tuesday, President Trump ranged across many topics, sprinkling questionable assertions throughout his remarks.

title: U.K.-Huawei, Europe Economy, China: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Whats on TV Wednesday: First Cow and The Line
description: FIRST COW (2020) Buy on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. At a settlement in the Oregon Territory in the mid-19th century, two men set up shop on a patch of ground. Their product, fried dough with modest garnish, sells out almost instantly. The secret ingredient? Stolen milk. The buddies who cook up that clever racket are at the heart of this latest western from Kelly Reichardt. When First Cow introduces Cookie (John Magaro) and King-Lu (Orion Lee), theyre strangers: Cookie is working as a cook and forager for a group of trappers; King-Lu is on the run. The friendship they develop together  and their covert dairy operation  is explored against a forested frontier backdrop. A.O. Scott called the film deceptively simple and wondrously subtle in his review for The New York Times. A parable of economics and politics, with shrewd insights into the workings of supply and demand, scarcity and scale and other puzzles of the marketplace, the movie is also keenly attuned to details of history, both human and natural, he wrote.

title: In Rare Surge of Online Unity, Iranians Call for Halt to Executions
description: Iranians from all walks of life  teachers, doctors, designers, cooks, actors, directors, artists, homemakers, bloggers  have taken to social media with a message for the government: Stop the executions.

title: Seoul Will Investigate #MeToo Accusations Against Dead Mayor
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Seoul City Hall officials said on Wednesday that they would create a joint fact-finding team with womens groups and legal and human rights experts to investigate accusations that Mayor Park Won-soon had sexually abused a secretary for four years.

title: ViacomCBS Fires Nick Cannon, Citing Anti-Semitic Podcast Remarks
description: The television star Nick Cannon was fired by ViacomCBS on Tuesday for making anti-Semitic remarks during a recent podcast in which he discussed conspiracy theories about Jewish people and praised a minister notorious for anti-Jewish comments.

title: Republicans Wont Do Much Convening in Florida, Colbert Thinks
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Were all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Trump Isnt the Worst Pandemic President
description: Just ask Brazilians.

title: She Tested Negative for Lyme Disease. So What Was Wrong?
description: The 50-year-old physician dropped into the leather chair in her psychiatrists Manhattan office. Her new normal, she announced to Dr. Deborah Cabaniss, was constant fatigue. Cabaniss noted that although her patient looked put together as usual, she could see the exhaustion in her eyes. You dont look like yourself, the therapist agreed.

title: The Wealthy Can't Stop Not Paying Their Taxes
description: Budget cuts have left the I.R.S. unable to chase down wealthy tax evaders.

title: Living With Aphantasia, the Inability to Make Mental Images
description: When I was in elementary school, I occasionally had trouble falling asleep, and people would tell me to count sheep. I had seen the activity graphically depicted in cartoons, but when I tried it, I never saw anything  just black. Ive been counting silently into the darkness for years.

title: The Herculean Effort to Build an American Army
description: THE RISE OF THE G.I. ARMY, 1940-1941The Forgotten Story of How America Forged a Powerful Army Before Pearl HarborBy Paul Dickson

title: Gardening Made Me Happier. It Will Work for You Too.
description: When Im angry  which is often these days  I pull weeds. Getting my hands in the dirt untangles the knots that form in my stomach. With the first few weeds, I feel my exasperation with those who refuse to wear masks relent. It takes a little more digging and pulling to address the rage that builds up each day while I listen to friends and colleagues who have been mistreated by the food-media organizations that are now being exposed for systemic racial injustices.

title: Trump Isnt the Worst Pandemic President
description: Whos the worlds worst leader at handling the pandemic? Easy. Donald Trump. Right? Well, as terrible as Mr. Trump is, a Brazilian YouTube star, Felipe Neto, argues its actually his president, Jair Bolsonaro.

title: How Exercise May Bolster the Brain
description: Exercise may help change exercisers brains in surprising ways, according to a new study of physical activity and brain health. The study, which included both mice and people, found that exercise prompts the liver to pump out a little-known protein, and that chemically upping the levels of that protein in out-of-shape, elderly animals rejuvenates their brains and memories. The findings raise provocative questions about whether the brain benefits of exercise might someday be available in a capsule or syringe form  essentially exercise in a pill.

title: Its Long Past Time to Get That Beard Under Control
description: Some men working from home and growing beards for the first time are coming to the realization that their facial hair is a tangle of waves and curls. But Matt Vilanova discovered how unmanageable his beard can be years ago.

title: The Return of Jane Elliott
description: The day after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in 1968, the schoolteacher Jane Elliott scrapped her lesson plan  teaching her third graders the Sioux prayer about not judging another person until you have walked a mile in his moccasins  for an experiential learning exercise.

title: White Fragility Is Everywhere. But Does Antiracism Training Work?
description: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Please Dont Call Them Heroes
description: In America, you should always get a little suspicious when politicians suddenly start calling you a hero. Its a well-worn trick; theyre buttering you up before sacrificing you to the gods of unconstrained capitalism and governmental neglect.

title: Music as a Means to an End
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: Your Ancestors Knew Death in Ways You Never Will
description: Nearly 140,000 Americans have been lost to coronavirus, and many experts fear that the deaths will only accelerate in the fall as cold weather forces us indoors. By years end, half as many Americans may have died as did in the four years of World War II.

title: Ben Bernanke: I Was Chairman of the Federal Reserve. Save the States.
description: The coronavirus pandemic has set loose a recession of shocking speed and severity. In the coming months, the actions taken by both the public and the private sectors will have economic and public health repercussions that will reverberate for years.

title: The Phantom Handbag
description: I feel it sometimes, like a phantom limb, banging against my side as I move around the house. I sense it nestled in the crook of my arm as I wander from room to room. It was the one-time receptacle of all I held immediately important: purse, receipts, identification, charger, books, tissues (fresh and used), flask, tampons, a card for that delicious but inexpensive Italian restaurant from that onetime a few months back.

title: Youre Doomscrolling Again. Heres How to Snap Out of It.
description: Your phone alarm goes off at 6 in the morning. You check some news sites and Facebook. Its bad news after bad news. Coronavirus cases keep climbing, and so do deaths. Children cant go back to school. Your favorite restaurant and barbershop are still closed. People are losing their jobs.

title: Teenage Angst, Revisited in Isolation
description: When Meera Parat decided to leave her one-bedroom apartment in Seattle and return to her childhood home in Palo Alto, Calif., she figured she would be staying for a few weeks.

title: What Is Betsy DeVos Thinking?
description: As the coronavirus continues to wreak havoc across the United States, some public K-12 schools may be able to reopen safely, but doing so will not be cheap. A recent report from the Council of Chief State School Officers estimated that public K-12 schools will need as much as $245 billion in additional funding to open with the recommended protocols in place from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Yet with local and state budgets strapped, many schools are likely to fall short unless they receive considerable federal support.

title: New York City Has 2,300 Parks. But Poor Neighborhoods Lose Out.
description: Governors Island, a 172-acre oasis in the middle of New York Harbor, has become one of New Yorks Citys most popular summer playgrounds with hammocks, biking and spectacular water views.

title: New Twists on Home-Sharing: 4 Airbnb Alternatives
description: In 2017, Victoria OConnell rented her London apartment via a home-sharing site to a man who looted and wrecked the place during a party that drew the police. He disappeared, but left her a review on the platform, saying, Great host.

title: Trump Weakens Major Conservation Law to Speed Construction Permits
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump on Wednesday unilaterally weakened one of the nations bedrock conservation laws, the National Environmental Policy Act, limiting public review of federal infrastructure projects to speed up the permitting of freeways, power plants and pipelines.

title: Pray for Your Poor Uncle, a Predatory Priest Told His Victims
description: Rain fell in New York City four days before Christmas of 2018. Francis M. had planned to be in the city that day for business, but he had dutifully put aside time when asked to answer questions at the Archdiocese of New York offices about his experiences with Uncle Ted  former Cardinal Theodore McCarrick.

title: A Resurgence of the Virus, and Lockdowns, Threatens Economic Recovery
description: WASHINGTON  The United States economy is headed for a tumultuous autumn, with the threat of closed schools, renewed government lockdowns, empty stadiums and an uncertain amount of federal support for businesses and unemployed workers all clouding hopes for a rapid rebound from recession.

title: Their Workers Kept Being Stopped by the Police, So They Decided to Help
description: The employees of Grandchamps, a Haitian restaurant in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn, were closing up after a long, hot day of filling takeout orders in early June when the owners asked them to gather in the dining area.

title: What Black Lives Matter Has Revealed About Small-Town America
description: CHAMBERSBURG, Pa.  Nikki Wilkerson was used to thinking of herself as the small brown girl growing up in rural Pennsylvania.

title: Just Let Those Kids Dance: Finding a Way for the Show to Go On
description: RANDALLSTOWN, Md.  On a sweltering Sunday afternoon in July, families sat in folding chairs arranged in socially distant clusters in the half-empty parking lot of a strip mall.

title: Living In ... The West Village
description: The neighborhoods low-key, small-scale charms are gradually returning following the lockdown, although residential sales and prices are way down.

title: The West Village: A Pause, and a Reset, for a Coveted Area
description: Store owners have barricaded their shops. West Fourth Street is missing its brunch-hour crowds. And shouting about masks occasionally erupts in packed Hudson River Park.

title: As U.S. Coronavirus Cases Hit 3.5 Million, Officials Scramble to Add Restrictions
description: Follow our live updates of coronavirus cases and deaths globally.

title: The Wave of Gun Violence in N.Y.C.
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: Apple Scores Legal Victory Against $14.9 Billion E.U. Tax Demand
description: LONDON  Apple won a major legal victory on Wednesday against European antitrust regulators as a European court overruled a 2016 decision that ordered the company to pay $14.9 billion in unpaid taxes to Ireland.

title: China Vows to Retaliate After Trump Signs Hong Kong Sanctions Bill
description: China on Wednesday sharply criticized President Trumps moves to strip Hong Kong of its preferential trading status with the United States and clear the way for new sanctions on officials and companies there, vowing to retaliate with punitive measures of its own.

title: Who Made My Puzzle?
description: Burlingame, Calif., which is about 15 miles south of San Francisco.

title: They Go to Mommy First
description: Maggie Levine was on maternity leave from her job as a childrens librarian in Boston for the first few months of the pandemic, but she started working again in the middle of May. She and her husband, James Maher, an engineer, had no outside child care between mid-May and early July, while she was working from home and he was working part time from home and part time from the office. They were both caring for their baby, who is now 9 months old.

title: One Meat Plant, One Thousand Infections: Revisiting Achut Deng
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Yes, Its Already Time to Buy Bulbs for Fall Planting
description: Shopping for flower bulbs: Its one of the more joyful summertime garden chores, certainly better than dragging hoses and sprinklers around or keeping ahead of the most incorrigible weeds.

title: Statue of Black Protester Is Raised in Place of Bristol Slave Trader
description: LONDON  Jen Reid had never marched in a Black Lives Matter protest before she took to the streets of Bristol, England, on June 7. By the end of that angry day, she had clambered up to stand in the place of a 17th-century slave trader, whose bronze statue had been pulled down and dumped in the citys harbor.

title: A Different Cold War
description: The relationship between China and the United States continues to deteriorate, as The Timess Steven Lee Myers and Paul Mozur explain. The two countries are clashing over Hong Kong, digital technology, trade, the South China Sea and more.

title: Burberry is set to cut hundreds of jobs in its latest cost-saving drive.
description: The British luxury retailer Burberry plans to cut up to 500 jobs worldwide as it continues to grapple with the impact of the coronavirus on its business.

title: Now I Am Become Death: The Legacy of the First Nuclear Bomb Test
description: It was 1 a.m. on July 16, 1945, when J. Robert Oppenheimer met with an Army lieutenant general, Leslie Groves, in the parched landscape of Jornada del Muerto  Dead Mans Journey  a remote desert in New Mexico.

title: Sessions Falls in Alabama, and Gideon Rises in Maine
description: Jeff Sessions goes down, Trump retreats from a hard-line position on international student visas, and Biden announces an ambitious climate plan  just dont call it a Green New Deal. Its Wednesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

title: The Moment of Truth
description: A reminder to sign up for our DealBook Debrief call about Trumps Covid calculus with The Timess White House correspondent Maggie Haberman. Its on July 16 at 11 a.m. Eastern and you can R.S.V.P. here. (Want this in your inbox each day? Sign up here.)

title: Forest Rambo Eludes German Police 3 Days Into Sprawling Hunt
description: BERLIN  The call to the German police on Sunday seemed a bit odd but routine enough. A man armed with a bow and arrow had been squatting illegally in a small shed outside the village of Oppenau in the foothills of the Black Forest.

title: Monsoon Rains Pummel South Asia, Displacing Millions
description: When heavy floods started inundating her riverside home last week in the village of Madarganj, northern Bangladesh, Habiba Begum chose to stay put with her family instead of moving to shelter.

title: Victory Gardens Were More About Solidarity Than Survival
description: In the latest article from Beyond the World War II We Know, a series from The Times that documents lesser-known stories from World War II, we recount the history of victory gardens and some of the misconceptions of how they emerged after the United States joined the conflict.

title: Homesick Student Cycles From Scotland to Greece During the Pandemic
description: LONDON  Nearly a month into the coronavirus lockdown, Kleon Papadimitriou, a Greek student in Aberdeen, Scotland, was feeling homesick.

title: 2020 Election Updates: Polls Suggest Trump Is Losing His Edge on the Economy
description: [Follow the DNC Live: Bidens speech, schedule, start time, streaming and more.]

title: Western Outbreaks Threaten Tourist Season at National Parks
description: GRAND CANYON NATIONAL PARK, Ariz.  Glowing purple and scarlet in fading afternoon light, the geological marvel that is the Grand Canyon, the crown jewel of Americas national park system, draws more than six million global visitors in a normal year and fuels the economy of Arizona.

title: Buying tech stocks is the most crowded trade in history.
description: For the past 25 years, Bank of America has surveyed fund managers about how they are positioning their portfolios. When a consensus emerges, the banks pollsters say, investors generally profit by betting against it, according to todays DealBook newsletter.

title: The Guardian, seeing unsustainable losses, will cut 180 jobs.
description: The British newspaper The Guardian said on Wednesday it would cut 12 percent of its work force, about 180 jobs, as it faces a shortfall of 25 million pounds ($31.5 million) caused by the economic impact of the pandemic.

title: The Tahini War: The Food at the Center of an Arab Gay Rights Battle
description: TEL AVIV  When Julia Zaher, the owner of a company that makes some of the most popular tahini in Israel, made a donation to an Israeli gay rights group recently, she saw it as an unremarkable act.

title: Why You May Not Be Able to Get a Coronavirus Test in California
description: Good morning.

title: What You Get for $1.3 Million
description: An artists studio and cottage in Greenport, N.Y.; a Tudor Revival house in Shaker Heights, Ohio; and a two-bedroom condo in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: $1.3 Million Homes in New York, Ohio and California
description: Once the community laundry facility for Greenport, a fishing village on the North Fork of Long Island, the property was later the studio of Rob Pruitt, an artist who sold it, in 2006, to Clay Weiner, a writer and director for television, film and advertising. Mr. Pruitt oversaw its most recent renovations into a live-work space.

title: In Publishing, Everything Is Up for Change
description: Getting to the top in book publishing has traditionally been a plodding and prolonged climb  and once you got there, you didnt leave. Knopf has had four publishers in its 105-year history. Farrar, Straus and Giroux has only been run by two people since John C. Farrar, Roger W. Straus and Robert Giroux.

title: Coronavirus Tests Can Be Scary for Kids. Heres How to Make Them Easier.
description: Cynthia Jaeger was packing up the family minivan for the two-hour trip from her house in Richmond, Va., to Washington, D.C., when her 8-year-old daughter began having an anxiety attack. Zoey, Jaegers middle child, has a rare neurological condition, and she needed to go to Childrens National Hospital for chemotherapy and intensive cognitive testing.

title: Myanmar Plan to Breed Protected Species in Captivity Draws Criticism
description: BANGKOK  Myanmar will soon adopt rules that would permit captive breeding of about 175 threatened species, including tigers, pangolins and Irrawaddy dolphins, despite fears that such ventures could encourage poaching of wild animals and spawn new diseases that jump to humans.

title: Clean Lines and Shiraz Vines in Rural Israel
description: This 1.5-acre farm in the Lower Galilee region of Israel, with a four-bedroom house and a separate guesthouse, is on the market for $4.3 million.

title: House Hunting in Israel: A Modern Stone Farmhouse on 1.5 Acres
description: This Israeli version of a Mediterranean country home faces northwest toward the biblical Mount Tabor in the Lower Galilee region east of Haifa, Israels third-largest city.

title: Tyra Banks Is Tapped as New Dancing With the Stars Host
description: A day after Tom Bergeron, the longtime Dancing With the Stars host, announced on Twitter that ABC had not invited him to return for the shows 29th season, the network revealed his replacement: Tyra Banks, the former supermodel and businesswoman.

title: The Feds top regulator warns that global markets could turn messy.
description: Randal Quarles, the Federal Reserves top bank regulator and chair of the global Financial Stability Board, warned that markets could gyrate again and that it was possible investors were setting the stage for a sharp drop in asset prices.

title: Five Art Accounts to Follow on Instagram Now
description: When things are tough at home, I sometimes search Instagram for street photographers abroad. Its not that Im looking for happy scenes, necessarily. Its just reassuring to be reminded that the world is so much larger than our national news cycle. (Scrolling through digital feeds is also the safest way to travel these days, not to mention the most eco-friendly.) These are the five accounts that Ive been turning to lately for quick little doses of our common humanity; other New York Times critics will be posting their own favorites regularly.

title: A Plague on Your Houses: Reading Covid-19 Into Disease Onstage
description: The hateful plague spreads like a raging wildfire, devouring the city without mercy, emptying homes and filling the streets with moans and wailing and heaps of rotting bodies, declares a priest in The Oedipus Project, Theater of War Productions recent reading of scenes from Oedipus the King, translated and directed by Bryan Doerries.

title: Turn Your Relationship Into a Work of Art
description: As the coronavirus pandemic upended wedding plans and industry jobs, many couples rescheduled their engagement photo shoots in order to adhere to social distancing guidelines. Others hired illustrators to commemorate their upcoming nuptials, ceremonies and other relationship milestones. Here are a few creative examples from artists.

title: Covid-19 Risk Doesnt Depend (Much) on Blood Type, New Studies Find
description: Early in the Covid-19 pandemic, researchers found preliminary evidence suggesting that peoples blood type might be an important risk factor  both for being infected by the virus and for falling dangerously ill.

title: Your New Favorite Sandwich
description: Good morning. The chef Brooks Headley is in the spotlight today, with his recipe for the crispy chicken-fried tofu sandwich (above) served at his Superiority Burger on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Its a bit of a project as most restaurant recipes tend to be, but its neither complicated nor difficult. If you start the process this afternoon, youll eat a sandwich of intense deliciousness for dinner and be thankful for having done so, against the backdrop of our troubled, reeling world.

title: Our 2020-21 Student Contest Calendar
description: Updates: Watch our free on-demand webinar about teaching with our contests. Also, here is a printable PDF of this contest calendar.

title: How Do You Translate a Comic Book Into Audio? Ask Neil Gaiman
description: This is what dreaming sounds like.

title: Citing Educational Risks, Scientific Panel Urges That Schools Reopen
description: Wading into the contentious debate over reopening schools, an influential committee of scientists and educators on Wednesday recommended that, wherever possible, younger children and those with special needs should attend school in person.

title: You May Not Know These 15 Songs. But Youve Heard Them.
description: Sampling Is (a) Creative or (b) Theft, read a New York Times headline in 1997, summarizing a debate that has raged ever since songs started incorporating parts of other songs. The truth? Its a little of both, and thats whats so fun about it.

title: Walmart, Nations Largest Retailer, Will Require Customers to Wear Masks
description: In perhaps the strongest statement yet by a major American company about the importance of masks, Walmart said it would require that all of its customers wear face coverings starting next week.

title: Scientists Accidentally Bred the Fish Version of a Liger
description: At first glance, American paddlefish and Russian sturgeon seem about as different as two fish can be.

title: Trump Raises New Objections to Subpoena Seeking His Tax Returns
description: Days after the U.S. Supreme Court delivered a defeat to President Trump, clearing the way for the Manhattan district attorney to seek his tax returns, his lawyers on Wednesday renewed their efforts to block or at least narrow access to the records.

title: After Attacks From Trump Aides, Fauci Says Lets Stop This Nonsense and Focus on Virus
description: WASHINGTON  After several days spent weathering attacks from White House officials, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci hit back on Wednesday, calling recent efforts to discredit him bizarre and a hindrance to the governments ability to communicate information about the coronavirus pandemic.

title: God Did Not Commute Roger Stones Sentence
description: This article is part of Frank Brunis free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it every Wednesday.

title: The City I Love and Climate Change: A Miami Story
description: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

title: Smithsonian Chief Says He Will Look Into Staff Complaint of Racism
description: Lonnie G. Bunch III, who last year became the first Black secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, said in an interview Wednesday that is he reviewing complaints in a letter sent by former employees and board members of its National Museum of African Art that described it as a bad place for Black employees.

title: How a Famous Harvard Professor Became a Target Over His Tweets
description: Steven Pinker occupies a role that is rare in American life: the celebrity intellectual. The Harvard professor pops up on outlets from PBS to the Joe Rogan podcast, translating dense subjects into accessible ideas with enthusiasm. Bill Gates called his most recent book my new favorite book of all time.

title: For Paris Mens Wear, the Next Stop Is California
description: We have seen the future of European fashion, and it is California.

title: How Artists Are Trying to Solve the Worlds Problems
description: Janine Soleils passing was sudden and shocking. She died a week after her 75th birthday in May, which was spent in hospice care after contracting the novel coronavirus. And once she was gone, her son, the artist Dylan Gauthier, found her digital imprint everywhere: on the dating websites where she found love, on the insurance company listings for her old therapy practice and across the hundreds of other websites she had tacitly agreed to share personal data with.

title: Metropolitan Museum of Art to Reopen Five Days a Week in August
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced on Wednesday that its landmark location on Fifth Avenue will welcome visitors five days a week, Thursday through Monday, when it reopens to the public on Aug. 29.

title: These Creamy Tomatoes Are the Ideal Lunch for One
description: One of the joys of working from home is being able to make myself something for lunch that no one else in my family even remotely likes.

title: A Heat Wave, the Coronavirus: Double Spikes of Risk Hit Communities
description: For much of the United States, the last several days have been brutal: record temperatures recorded around the country, and coronavirus case numbers are on the rise as well, complicating efforts to protect people at risk.

title: Wagner in the Parking Lot as Opera Returns to Germany
description: BERLIN  The Rhinemaidens lament their lost gold on asphalt. Tristan savors doomed love in a stately 17th-century garden. A motley crew of playboys and deposed royalty are set adrift in an industrial harbor.

title: Oklahoma Governor Tests Positive for Coronavirus
description: Gov. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma announced on Wednesday that he tested positive for the coronavirus, becoming the first governor in the United States known to have been infected during the pandemic.

title: Just Collect Less Data, Period.
description: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

title: How I May Destroy You Got Its Stunning Soundtrack
description: In the world of I May Destroy You, the critically hailed HBO/BBC series written, co-directed by and starring Michaela Coel, few things are ever static. The show, like its central characters  young, exuberantly liberated but inherently vulnerable Black Britons navigating sex, power and friendship in a very recent London  is held together by the cumulative force of its apparent contradictions.

title: Playwrights Horizons Details First Season Under New Leadership
description: In his first season at the helm of Playwrights Horizons, Adam Greenfield is sending a message: The organization may be staging fewer shows because of the pandemic  four in its 2021 season, down from the six that were slated for the 2019-2020 season  but it is committed to showcasing work by writers of color.

title: Theater Streams See Stars Pop Up in Unexpected Places
description: One of theaters great pleasures is watching actors bring characters to life. The era of online performing arts has added a remarkably democratic element by allowing high-caliber casts to pop up in everything from revisited classics to fresh-from-the-oven efforts by young playwrights. Most stars are available on short notice these days, after all, and now they can take on projects that time or financial constraints may have kept them away from. We look for whatever upside we can find, and the pleasure of fine acting in an unexpected setting has been a balm.

title: Airlines May Learn to Love the Boeing 737 Max Again
description: The first half of the year was not kind to the 737 Max. Boeing froze production of its beleaguered plane from January through much of May as customers canceled hundreds of orders, and deals for hundreds more were put at risk by delays in the planes return to the skies and the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Country Music Struggles to Meet the Moment. Again.
description: Scornful and indignant, Eric Church  the most accessible of country musics contemporary heretics  begins his new single, Stick That in Your Country Song, with an image of a decayed America:

title: Governor of Oklahoma Says He Tested Positive for Coronavirus
description: Gov. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma announced during a virtual news conference that he was the first governor to test positive for the coronavirus.

title: Chief Vaccine Scientist Will Not Be Forced to Disclose Pharmaceutical Stocks
description: WASHINGTON  The scientist leading the Trump administrations coronavirus vaccine program will be allowed to remain a government contractor, a decision that permits him to avoid ethics disclosures required of federal employees and maintain his investments in pharmaceutical companies.

title: Tuberville Advances: Will Alabama Send an Auburn Coach to the Senate?
description: Tommy Tuberville, who made his name as one of the most successful football coaches at Auburn, won in overtime and now faces an intrastate rival in Alabama.

title: The Sims Is Bringing Its Inclusive Spirit to TV
description: Deep down, Rayvon Owen already knew he was gay when a classmate introduced him to the Sims back in 2003, when they were in sixth grade in Richmond, Va.

title: 10 Things I Hate About Taxes
description: Lindsay, welcome back to your 15th year with our online tax prep service! We have just a few simple questions to help you get started.

title: Cant Match Netflix? At Least You Can Buy Some British Shows
description: When you want to start a streaming service and your most established competitor has for years been spending billions of dollars making and acquiring exclusive series, what do you do?

title: Bob Baffert Suspended 15 Days for Drug Positives
description: The Arkansas Racing Commission suspended the Hall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert for 15 days on Wednesday and vacated the victories of two of his horses after they tested positive for a banned substance.

title: The Golf Party in This Ohio Town Has It All, Except Fans
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  In a typical year, the Bogey Inn would be preparing to party this week. While PGA Tour golfers ply their trade at nearby Muirfield Village Golf Club, site of the Memorial Tournament, the sports bar would welcome an overflow crowd of fans to enjoy a live band on its expansive patio outfitted with a disco ball.

title: Hollywood Stays Away From Facebook Ad Boycott
description: LOS ANGELES  More than 1,000 companies have halted their Facebook advertising over the past month as part of a protest over the social networks handling of hate speech, with most major industries represented in the boycott.

title: Former Manhattan Federal Prosecutor Fired by Trump to Teach at Stanford
description: Geoffrey S. Berman, the former U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York who was abruptly fired last month by President Trump, will be a visiting professor at Stanford Law School for the fall 2020 term, the school said on Wednesday.

title: Complaint Faults Museum Director for Hanging His In-Laws El Greco
description: It was a chance to borrow a rarely seen El Greco for a museum that had only a single painting by the old master.

title: How Will Your Life Change if Congress Cuts Your Jobless Benefits?
description: On July 26, an unemployment insurance benefits program providing an extra $600 per week to more than 30 million jobless Americans will expire.

title: Teenage Suspect Charged in Fatal Shooting of 8-Year-Old Girl in Atlanta
description: A teenager was charged on Wednesday in the fatal shooting of Secoriea Turner, an 8-year-old girl who died this month in Atlanta after an armed group stopped her familys car and opened fire, officials said.

title: What to Do When Most Days Feel Like Wednesdays
description: Welcome. How are you? Wednesdays were a bear even before the pandemic came to town and made most days feel like Wednesdays. Now Wednesdays are like Wednesdays squared, like Nebraska on a cross-country drive, 456 miles from Omaha in the East all the way to the Wyoming line. Theyre a long way from a weekend that is hardly a weekend for many, in both directions on the calendar.

title: TikTok Enlists Army of Lobbyists as Suspicions Over China Ties Grow
description: WASHINGTON  TikTok, the wildly popular social media app known for its viral dance and lip sync clips, has been embraced by millions of students, celebrities and young adults across the United States. But the companys ties to China could cripple its existence.

title: Comet NEOWISE: How to See It in Night Skies
description: Eager sky watchers are turning to the heavens as Comet NEOWISE, one of the brightest comets in a generation, starts climbing ever higher among the evening stars.

title: Herms Introduces Seasonless Staples for the Long Haul
description: As the artistic director of womens ready-to-wear at Herms, Nadge Vanhe-Cybulski is deeply familiar with the fashion calendar, its shows and seasons coming at a quick but constant pace. Last spring, though, she was staring down the maternity leave she would soon take following the birth of her first child  an event that cant help but remake ones relationship with time  and found herself wanting to take advantage of the remaining weeks before she went. We decided to do this capsule collection wed always talked about, she says of her team, which works out of the brands atelier in Pantin, just north of Paris. Something special created out of season, when we can really explore.

title: Black Business Owners Had a Harder Time Getting Federal Aid, a Study Finds
description: Black business owners are more likely to be hindered in seeking coronavirus financial aid than their white peers, a new study has found.

title: Eating Fish May Protect the Brain From Pollutants
description: Eating fish could help protect the brain against the detrimental effects of air pollution, a new study suggests.

title: Molly Neptune Parker, Basket Maker and Tribal Elder, Dies at 81
description: There were years when Molly Neptune Parker would work the night shift at a wool factory after putting in a full day making baskets and still be home in time to serve her children breakfast.

title: 87 Face Felony Charges After Protesting Breonna Taylors Death
description: Dozens of protesters were charged with a felony on Tuesday after they gathered on property owned by Kentuckys attorney general to demand charges against the police officers responsible for the shooting death of Breonna Taylor.

title: Eat the Buddha Reports From the World Capital of Self-Immolations
description: In The Unwomanly Face of War, an oral history of World War II, the Nobel Prize-winning writer Svetlana Alexievich recounts a strange little story. A woman leaps into dark water to rescue a drowning man. At the shore, however, she realizes it is not a man she has hauled from the water but a gigantic sturgeon. The sturgeon dies.

title: When the President Shows You an Old Man Shouting White Power
description: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced that the U.S. would impose visa restrictions for Huawei and other tech employees and their families.

title: Waiting for a Covid-19 Vaccine, and Worrying About It
description: To the Editor:

title: States Sue Education Dept. Over Relief for Cheated Students
description: Twenty-two states and the District of Columbia sued the Education Department on Wednesday, claiming it broke federal law in adopting new rules for a program meant to wipe out the student loan debt of borrowers whose schools defrauded them.

title: Life Inside the N.B.A. Bubble
description: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Steins weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

title: Burning Ships in Iran Add to String of Dozens of Explosions and Fires
description: A large fire broke out at a shipyard in the southern Iranian port city of Bushehr on Wednesday, burning seven ships and sending plumes of black smoke billowing above the city skyline, according to videos and Iranian media reports.

title: Meet the 19-Year-Old From Kazakhstan Who Remixed Roses Into a Hit
description: Imanbek Zeikenov is 19 years old and lives with his parents in the small village of Aksu in Kazakhstan. He studied railway engineering at school, and until last December, held a day job at his local train station. But everything changed in the summer of 2019, when he discovered a song called Roses by the Guyanese-American rapper and singer Saint Jhn.

title: Bari Weiss: A Fiery Parting Shot at The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: We Are Dangerously Close, Lightfoot Warns Amid Rise in Cases
description: Mayor Lori Lightfoot of Chicago said that the citys young people were not taking the virus seriously enough and suggested she would increase restrictions.

title: That Siberian Heat Wave? Yes, Climate Change Was a Big Factor
description: This years startling heat across much of Siberia would have been all but impossible without human influence on climate change, researchers have concluded.

title: For U.K.s Minority Women, Economic Toll of Lockdown Lingers
description: LONDON  Within 10 days of the British governments lockdown announcement in late March, one woman lost all nine of her cleaning jobs. Another was laid off from a laundromat after she requested a mask, and a live-in nanny was fired for using public transport on her day off.

title: Asylum Officers Condemn What They Call Draconian Plans by Trump
description: WASHINGTON  A Trump administration plan to overhaul the asylum system in the United States would subject vulnerable families to danger and violate international law, officers who would carry out the policy said Wednesday.

title: A Brazen Online Attack Targets V.I.P. Twitter Users in a Bitcoin Scam
description: It was about 4 in the afternoon on Wednesday on the East Coast when chaos struck online. Dozens of the biggest names in America  including Joseph R. Biden Jr., Barack Obama, Kanye West, Bill Gates and Elon Musk  posted similar messages on Twitter: Send Bitcoin and the famous people would send back double your money.

title: Rev. Vickey Gibbs, Activist in a Progressive Church, Dies at 57
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: During the trial of a vaccine, the final test is also its biggest: Phase 3. Thats when the vaccine is given to tens of thousands of people, along with a placebo group, to determine its safety and effectiveness. Its the final step before a vaccine is approved and distributed to the public.

title: In Shadow of Pandemic, U.S. Drug Overdose Deaths Resurge to Record
description: After the first decrease in a quarter-century, in 2018, the number of deaths is again on the rise.

title: Dismemberment of Tech C.E.O. Fahim Saleh Looks Like Professional Job
description: [Update: A suspect is arrested in the murder of Fahim Saleh.]

title: Footage of Police Body Cameras Offers Devastating Account of Floyd Killing
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Almost from the moment George Floyd encountered the police on May 25, with a gun pointed at him, he appeared terrified and emotionally distraught, according to police camera footage that was newly made available for viewing Wednesday at a courthouse in downtown Minneapolis.

title: Anthony Fauci, Heat Wave, Hot Dogs: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Virus Is Stealing the Show, but Trump Is Sticking With Reruns
description: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. Im Lisa Lerer, your host.

title: With Dueling Environmental Events, Trump and Biden Define the Race
description: President Trump traveled on Wednesday to the new political battleground of Georgia to blast away at one of the nations cornerstone conservation laws, vowing to speed construction projects by limiting legally mandated environmental reviews of highways, pipelines and power plants.

title: Can Doug Jones Fend Off Tommy Tuberville and Trump in Alabama?
description: MOBILE, Ala.  On Tuesday evening, addressing supporters and the news media after his runaway victory in the Alabama Senate Republican primary, Tommy Tuberville wasted no time in pivoting toward his general-election opponent this fall, Senator Doug Jones. In Mr. Joness Alabama, he said, You dont work for the United States of America  you spend your first three years trying to impeach the best president weve ever had. And he voted to impeach him!

title: Sole Source Contract for Covid-19 Database Draws Scrutiny From Democrats
description: Update, July 17, 2020: After publication of this article, the Department of Health and Human Services said a mistake on the federal contracting site USASpending.gov made it appear that the $10.2 million contract to run a centralized Covid-19 database was given to a solitary bidder. The Department said TeleTracking Technologies, which was awarded the contract, was one of six bids. The Department says the error on the federal website is being corrected.

title: Who Can Make Trump Miserable This Fall?
description: I hope by now youve managed to come to grips with the fact that were no longer going to have Jeff Sessions in our lives.

title: U.S. Weighs Sweeping Travel Ban on Chinese Communist Party Members
description: The Trump administration is considering a sweeping ban on travel to the United States by members of the Chinese Communist Party and their families, according to people familiar with the proposal, a move that would almost certainly prompt retaliation against Americans seeking to enter or remain in China and exacerbate tensions between the two nations.

title: North Macedonia Election Returns No Clear Winner
description: BERLIN  The first general election in North Macedonia since the country changed its name and resolved a longstanding dispute with neighboring Greece has ended with no clear winner, leaving the countrys future diplomatic trajectory in the balance.

title: Why Does the N.Y.P.D. Want to Punish Journalists?
description: Increased public scrutiny of American policing through cellphone videos, social media and mass protests has revealed in recent weeks an urgent need for sustained and systemic reform. The New York Police Department has chosen to respond by pressing ahead with new rules to grant wider latitude to bar journalists from covering official police activity.

title: Corrections: July 16, 2020
description: An article on Monday about oil and gas companies that are heading toward bankruptcy misidentified the scientific agency where Claus Zehner works. It is the European Space Agency, not the SRON Netherlands Institute for Space Research.

title: Trump Replaces Brad Parscale as Campaign Manager, Elevating Bill Stepien
description: President Trump on Wednesday shook up his re-election team with less than four months until Novembers vote, replacing his campaign manager, Brad Parscale, in an acknowledgment of the presidents diminished standing in nearly all public and private polling since the spring.

title: George Floyds Family Files Lawsuit Against Officers
description: A lawyer for George Floyds family, Benjamin Crump, filed a civil rights lawsuit on Wednesday against the city of Minneapolis and the four officers who were charged with his killing

title: Airbnb Says Its I.P.O. Plans Are Back on Track
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Airbnb has resumed its efforts to go public, despite significant damage to the home rental business caused by the coronavirus pandemic, Airbnbs chief executive, Brian Chesky, told employees Wednesday.

title: Quotation of the Day: Economic Damage of Lockdown Lingers for Minority Women in Britain
description: They phoned me one by one to say dont come. Each call was like a bomb, blasting every bit of my livelihood until I had no work left.

title: Top N.Y.P.D. Chief Injured While Making Arrest at a Protest
description: New York Citys top uniformed police officer, two lieutenants and a sergeant were injured on Wednesday in two separate incidents on the Brooklyn Bridge, including one that involved an attack with some kind of stick or pole as protesters marched nearby, officials said.

title: Witchcraft
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  By the pricking of my thumbs, / Something wicked this way comes. So says the second witch in Act IV, Scene 1 of that Scottish play.

title: Chinas Economy Rebounds From Coronavirus, but Shares Fall
description: BEIJING  Economies in Europe and the United States are still languishing as the pandemic forces cities to shut down and shoppers to stay home. But one major country is growing once again: China.

title: Its Been 75 Years, and America Still Wont Admit a Nuclear Disaster
description: When America detonated the worlds first atomic bomb at 0529 hours on July 16, 1945, it was an attack on American soil.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Black and other ethnic minority women in Britain are being disproportionately affected by the financial and psychological toll from the coronavirus outbreak, even as the economy reopens.

title: Whats on TV Thursday: Brave New World and Little Voice
description: BRAVE NEW WORLD Stream on Peacock. Aldous Huxleys 1932 dystopian novel, Brave New World, has been ripped from the hands of your high school English teacher and thrown onscreen with this new TV adaptation. One of the highest-profile titles from NBCUniversals new streaming service, Peacock, the show brings to life the futuristic New London, a city where crime and disease are in the past, and residents spend their time popping happy pills and having orgies. At the storys center are Bernard (Harry Lloyd) and Lenina (Jessica Brown Findlay), two New Londoners who bring a pair of outsiders, played by Alden Ehrenreich and Demi Moore, into the city. While the creators of the series make an effort to cook up a version of Huxleys vision that feels fresh to 21st-century audiences, James Poniewozik wrote in his review for The New York Times that the show ultimately transmutes a provocative warning into a vision of a sci-fi world that feels neither brave nor new.

title: A Team by Any Other Name Is Fine, It Turns Out
description: When team owner Abe Pollin decided to change the name of the N.B.A.s Washington Bullets in 1995, the two-year rebranding process had the veneer of a democratic undertaking.

title: Fatal Affair Review: Close Stalker
description: There is so much recycled material in Fatal Affair that its carbon footprint must have been zero. Thats the good news in this Netflix dance of dj vu, one with scarcely a camera move, plot swerve or line of dialogue that hasnt already graced myriad romantic thrillers and special-victim police procedurals.

title: Late Night Thinks the Trumps Are Full of Beans
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Were all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Bristol Removes Statue of Black Protester After Just One Day
description: LONDON  Jen Reid, the Black Lives Matter protester whose statue was erected in place of a toppled slave trader in Bristol, England, on Wednesday, said just before the unauthorized installation that she did not know whether the citys authorities would let it stand there for a few months or a single day.

title: E.U. Court Strikes Down Trans-Atlantic Data Transfer Pact
description: LONDON  Europes top court on Thursday struck down a trans-Atlantic agreement that allows scores of companies to move data between the European Union and the United States, causing uncertainty for businesses that rely on moving digital information seamlessly around the world.

title: U.S. Wants to Bar Members of Chinas Communist Party. Who Are They?
description: As the Trump administration weighs a travel ban against the members of the Chinese Communist Party and their relatives, it is considering cutting off a vast sector of Chinese society  92 million people  that often defies stereotypes, including those who walk the halls of power in Beijing, supervise Chinas schools and run major companies.

title: Putins People Documents the Ruthless and Relentless Reach of Kremlin Corruption
description: In the years that it took the journalist Catherine Belton to research and write Putins People, her voluminous yet elegant account of money and power in the Kremlin, a number of her interview subjects tried various tactics to undermine her work. One of them, a close Putin ally apparently alarmed by her questions about Russian President Vladimir Putins activities as a K.G.B. agent in Dresden in the 1980s, emphatically insisted that any rumored links between the K.G.B. and terrorist organizations had never been proved: And you should not try to do so! he warned.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Wilderness Camping With a 9-Month-Old
description: Brian writes: My wife, Karen, and I are expecting. I want to bring our child to the Boundary Waters Canoe Area, a remote wilderness in Minnesota, where we go every year. Karen thinks that camping with a 9- to 12-month-old will be unenjoyable and dangerous. But how cool would it be for our child to be able to say theyve been to the B.W.C.A. every year of their life?!

title: He Wanted a Manhattan Bachelor Pad for Under $600,000. Which of These Would You Choose?
description: After failing to land a two-bedroom co-op he could share with a roommate, a young buyer scaled back his search. Heres where he wound up.

title: Must We Make Your Stepfathers Coronavirus Sickness a Political Issue?
description: My 24-year-old son and I bicker constantly over politics. He thinks Im hypnotized by Fox News. Im not, but Im not impressed by his knee-jerk liberal positions either. I never doubted our love for each other. But when Covid-19 came, he began accusing his stepfather and me of not taking the virus seriously. (Weve always followed our states mandates.) Now, my husband has become seriously ill with the virus. And my son has been nasty about it: blaming us and saying, I told you so, rather than helping me or being sympathetic. I am devastated. What can I do?

title: Silvia Moreno-Garcia Has Crafts Covered. Bring Your Own Scissors.
description: VALUE ADDED Spend some time lurking on websites of best-selling authors and youll be inspired by the clever ways theyve found to cheer up glum fans during the pandemic. Take Hank Green, whose novel A Beautifully Foolish Endeavor enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 4. He reminds you, Dont forget to be awesome, and lets you know hes discussing his book on Zoom, Crowdcast and YouTube. Rene Ahdieh, author of The Damned (No. 5 on the young adult list), not only offers advice (Persist. Always Persist), she also dishes about her least favorite mode of transportation (Alpaca. Definitely alpaca).

title: Are We Overreacting on Climate Change?
description: FALSE ALARMHow Climate Change Panic Costs Us Trillions, Hurts the Poor, and Fails to Fix the PlanetBy Bjorn Lomborg

title: Poem: The Bodys Uncontested Need to Devour: An Explanation
description: We stayed inside so long. The moss is calling us. The leaves, the little flickers  bow down. Major Jacksons mesmerizing fifth collection, The Absurd Man, conveys profound physical presences: connection to earth and memory, a deepest need for embodied contact in this often ridiculously abstracted modern world. His lush language invites us into the exquisite realms here at our feet  or beyond that tree, there, in the cracks between the old stones. Take it in, be fed, feel close to something elemental again. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye

title: Why Does America Have Old Leaders?
description: The American presidency is starting to feel like a gerontocracy.

title: Protests Continue Daily in Louisville. Heres a Look at 45 Days of Marches.
description: Kentuckys largest city has seen weeks of demonstrators demanding justice in the case of Breonna Taylor, who was killed by the police in her home there.

title: FaZe Clan President Departs: Its Time for Gaming to Clean Up Its Act
description: FaZe Clan, an esports lifestyle conglomerate, helped turn gamers into a new class of social media influencers. Now, several top executives behind FaZe Clan are leaving to start a competing organization called XSET.

title: Whats With All the Covid-Death Shaming?
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Ive made a few condolence calls during the past few months. None of the people I called to condole about had died of Covid-19. I was always given another reason.

title: Saying Goodbye to Totokaelo
description: The fashion industry is in a state of emergency. This has been made clear not only by the mounting bankruptcies of big-name retailers, but also by the closure of beloved smaller businesses. These are shops that wont bounce back.

title: A Conversation With Tammy Duckworth
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:

title: Not Everyone Hates School at Home
description: In the turmoil of this springs quarantine learning, one thing Pamela Ononiwu, of Fairfax County, Va., did not expect was that her three elementary school-age children might actually be happier learning at home.

title: Feeling Stuck? Five Tips for Managing Life Transitions
description: The Italians have a wonderful expression for how our lives get upended when we least expect it: lupus in fabula. It means the wolf in the fairy tale. Just when life is going swimmingly, along comes a demon, a dragon, a diagnosis, a downsizing. Just when our fairy tale seems poised to come true, a big, scary thing threatens to destroy everything around it.

title: Testing Is on the Brink of Paralysis. Thats Very Bad News.
description: As Covid-19 cases surge to their highest levels in dozens of states, the nations testing effort is on the brink of paralysis because of widespread delays in getting back results. And that is very bad news, because even if testing is robust, the pandemic cannot be controlled without rapid results.

title: My Small Alabama Town, Masked and Unmasked
description: AUBURN, Ala.  What is it like to live in this small college town during ordinary times? Its nice.

title: Colin Powell Still Wants Answers
description: Early one morning in August 2002, Jack Straw, the British foreign minister at the time, drove with a small entourage to a beach house in East Hampton on Long Island. The house belonged to the billionaire Ronald Lauder, who for most of August was hosting his good friend and Straws American counterpart, Colin Powell.

title: Even if the Polls Are Really Off, Trump Is Still in Trouble
description: Follow our live coverage of the 2020 election between Joe Biden and President Trump.

title: Washington State Beat Back Covid-19. Now Its Rising Again.
description: YAKIMA, Wash.  In what seems like almost a lifetime ago, Americas coronavirus story started in January in Washington State, with the nations first confirmed case followed by an early outbreak that spread with alarming ferocity.

title: She Waved a Rainbow Flag at Our Cairo Show. Tragedy Followed.
description: Last month, Sarah Hegazi, a 30-year-old Egyptian L.G.B.T.Q. rights activist, took her own life in Canada. Far away from Cairo, her home, she was profoundly haunted by what had happened to her there over the past two and a half years, having been arrested, tortured and hounded into exile. Her transgression? She raised the rainbow flag  unabashedly and joyously  at a concert in Cairo.

title: The Many Dimensions of the Chief Justices Triumphant Term
description: For once, the conventional wisdom was right: The Supreme Court term that ended last week was a triumph for Chief Justice John Roberts. But, as usual, the conventional wisdom skims the surface, focusing on the obvious: his steering of the court toward a center comfortably aligned with public opinion, and protecting it from an institutionally destructive alliance with a president who assumed the court would do his bidding.

title: North Carolina City Approves Reparations for Black Residents
description: As Americans debate how far the country should go to make amends for slavery and other racial injustices, a conversation reawakened by the killing of George Floyd, a city in North Carolina has taken the first step: It approved reparations for Black residents.

title: Ocasio-Cortez Pushes Cuomo to Back Billionaires Tax
description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has joined a new campaign to push Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to tax billionaires who live in New York State and use the money to assist people hurt by the pandemic-fueled economic crisis.

title: In the Same Towns, Private Schools Are Reopening While Public Schools Are Not
description: In Honolulu, nearly all public schools are planning to allow students to return for just part of the week. But at Punahou, a private school for grades kindergarten through 12, school will open full time for everyone.

title: Its a Tough Time to Be a Street Musician With a 900-Pound Piano
description: Colin Huggins, the piano man of Washington Square Park, sat at his Steinway baby grand the other day playing one of Claude Debussys frolicking arabesques. A few onlookers wore surgical masks and listened from benches. Elsewhere in the park, a Black Lives Matter protest was starting and a worker climbed up a ladder to scrub away graffiti from the Washington Arch.

title: To Make Orchestras More Diverse, End Blind Auditions
description: During the tumultuous summer of 1969, two Black musicians accused the New York Philharmonic of discrimination. Earl Madison, a cellist, and J. Arthur Davis, a bassist, said they had been rejected for positions because of their race.

title: Opera Can No Longer Ignore Its Race Problem
description: In late May, shortly after the killing of George Floyd, the mezzo-soprano JNai Bridges was invited by Los Angeles Opera to give a virtual recital.

title: Its Merkels Last Rodeo. Will a Pandemic Rescue Deal Seal Her Legacy?
description: BRUSSELS  Finishing her 15th year as chancellor of Germany, Angela Merkel, the European Unions longest-serving and most respected leader, now has her last, best chance to shape the future of the bloc and her own legacy.

title: Black Artists on How to Change Classical Music
description: With their major institutions founded on white European models and obstinately focused on the distant past, classical music and opera have been even slower than American society at large to confront racial inequity. Black players make up less than 2 percent of the nations orchestras; the Metropolitan Opera still has yet to put on a work by a Black composer.

title: Boom Time for Death Planning
description: One day in April, as the coronavirus ravaged New York City, 24-year-old Isabelle Rodriguez composed a tweet she would send from the grave.

title: Shootings Have Soared. Is the N.Y.P.D. Pulling Back?
description: First, a gunman shot a 23-year-old man in the leg on Monday afternoon in eastern Brooklyn, then fled in a red sport-utility vehicle.

title: Vacation in the Summer of Covid-19
description: Everyone the world over knows that travel has drastically changed. For many, the simple idea of travel is fraught, regardless of the current restrictions and border closures. But others still feel the need to get away, drawn to the appeal and respite of new  or familiar  sights and sounds and experiences.

title: Kicked Out of China, and Other Real-Life Costs of a Geopolitical Meltdown
description: LONDON  Soon after I was informed in mid-March that my journalist visa for China had been canceled, I faced a dilemma: what to do with my collection of wooden staffs used in a style of Chinese martial arts that I had been practicing for nearly 10 years.

title: U.S. Shatters Its Record of New Coronavirus Infections as Indias Caseload Hits a Million
description: Follow our live updates of coronavirus cases and deaths globally.

title: Unpacking Cuomos Covid-19 Poster
description: [Want to get New York Today by email? Heres the sign-up.]

title: Reopening, Warily: Revisiting Jasmine Lombrage
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Letting Your Insurer Ride Shotgun, for a Discounted Rate
description: Its like the Elf on the Shelf, but for car insurance. Call it the mole on the console.

title: Big Business in Bangladesh: Selling Fake Coronavirus Certificates
description: NEW DELHI  The Bangladeshi authorities have arrested the owner of a hospital who they said had sold migrant workers thousands of certificates showing a negative result on coronavirus tests, when in fact many tests were never performed.

title: Entering a Paris Theater, Warily, and Finding a Weight Lifted
description: After three months of coronavirus-related restrictions, the anxiety doesnt go away readily. Setting foot inside a Paris theater for the first time in late June, I worried that it was too soon. The audience sat on three sides of the Espace Cardins smaller stage  with appropriate gaps  and many people looked at one another furtively, as if to ask: Are we really doing this?

title: The pandemic has bolstered to start-ups that provide end-of-life services.
description: Before the pandemic, end-of-life start-ups  companies that help clients plan funerals, dispose of remains and process grief  had experienced steady to moderate growth. Their founders were mostly women who hoped a mix of technology, customization and fresh thinking could take on the fusty and predominantly male funeral and estate-planning industries.

title: Chinas economic rebound from the virus may be hard to sustain.
description: Chinas economy expanded 3.2 percent in the second quarter compared with the same period last year, officials said on Thursday. The recovery is a sign, with caveats, of the authoritarian governments success in bringing the outbreak under control with widespread testing and travel restrictions.

title: Whats Behind the Shootings?
description: Gun violence has been rising lately in some of the biggest American cities. Its happened in New York, Chicago, Philadelphia and, perhaps most notably, Minneapolis, the scene of the brutal killing of George Floyd and the intense protests that followed.

title: The Painted Bird Review: Horrors That Cant Be Unseen
description: The closure of theaters would seem to have gravely wounded The Painted Bird, whose nonstop horrors and nearly three-hour length demand a concentrated immersion. Whether the Czech screenwriter-producer-director Vaclav Marhouls ambitious adaptation of Jerzy Kosinskis 1965 novel quite translates to the screen is another matter.

title: Flannery Review: Stories About a Writer
description: This biographical documentary of the writer Flannery OConnor, directed by Mark Bosco and Elizabeth Coffman, is sporadically informative. But it mostly underscores the shortcomings of the varied methods it uses.

title: Blessed Child Review: Leaving the Fold, but Not Family
description: In Blessed Child, the director Cara Jones interrogates her relationship with the Unification Church, the religious movement  widely regarded as a cult  founded by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon. Jones grew up as a devoted member, but her attitude changed with her first marriage, which eventually led her to leave the group.

title: Dirt Music Review: Damaged Lovers and Dreamy Landscapes
description: Every so often, a movie comes along that isnt particularly good, yet somehow gets to you  even as your eyes start to roll, they cant look away. Dirt Music is one of those, a strangely fascinating delivery system for so much visual beauty that its flaws scrabble to gain a purchase. Rocky coves and marzipan beaches, glittering waves and pellucid shallows crowd the screen, at the center of which hulks a mostly shirtless Garrett Hedlund. Dirt Music may never be an award-winner, but boy, does it know its audience.

title: Father Soldier Son Review: Service and Sacrifice
description: Lately, in need of comfort and with time on your hands, you may have stumbled upon the YouTube genre of the military reunion video. Men and women from all branches of the armed forces rejoin their families in bite-sized morsels of uplift: With a shriek and a skitter of sandals on linoleum, a beaming figure in combat fatigues engulfs a kid in a hug that doesnt end until after the camera cuts. The moving, sincere, soulful Netflix documentary Father Soldier Son, directed by The New York Times Leslye Davis and Catrin Einhorn, is what happens when the camera keeps rolling.

title: Fauci Calls White House Criticism Bizarre
description: Fauci fights back while staying above the fray, and Trump strikes a blow at the Magna Carta of environmental law. Its Thursday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

title: Tough Day for Us at Twitter
description: A final reminder that we are holding a DealBook Debrief call at 11 a.m. Eastern today. Our special guest is Maggie Haberman, a star White House correspondent at The Times, who will discuss the Trump administrations approach to containing the coronavirus, reopening the economy and preparing for the election. She will also take your questions, which you can send to dealbook@nytimes.com. R.S.V.P. here to join the call. (Want this in delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.)

title: Shamima Begum, Who Joined ISIS in Syria, Can Return to U.K., Court Says
description: LONDON  Shamima Begum, a woman who traveled to Syria from London as a schoolgirl to join ISIS, should be allowed to return to appeal the governments decision to strip her of her British citizenship, a court ruled on Thursday.

title: The New Must-Have Museum Souvenir: Face Masks
description: LONDON  On Monday lunchtime, a steady trickle of people wandered into the gift shop of the National Gallery in the British capital, browsing souvenirs to mark their first visit to a museum since Britain started emerging from lockdown.

title: Online Map Collection Provides a Peek at New York Over the Centuries
description: When Alexander Hamilton stepped foot in New York City in 1772, the then-village of Brooklyn was more agricultural than artisan, more traditional than trendy.

title: A Big Convention Decision by Democrats, and a Play for White Suburban Voters by Trump
description: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.

title: Closest Pictures Ever Taken of Sun Show Tiny Campfire Flares
description: The first images from a new solar mission  the closest ever taken of the sun  reveal a ubiquitous burbling of miniature solar flares. The discovery may provide clues for how turbulence heats the atmosphere of the sun and drives the ebb and flow of solar wind, the high-velocity charged particles throughout the solar system that buffet Earth and the other planets.

title: Morgan Stanley reports record profits.
description: Most American banks have held up reasonably well during the pandemic. And then there is Morgan Stanley.

title: Bank of America sets aside another $4 billion to cover loan losses.
description: Bank of America said Thursday that it had added $4 billion to the pool of funds it keeps to cover credit losses as it prepares for customers to default on their loans at an increasing rate once the government programs designed to support Americans through the coronavirus crisis come to an end.

title: California Breaks a Record: 10,000 New Cases in a Day
description: Good morning.

title: As stores reopen, retailers say customer behavior is hit and miss.
description: The psyche of the American shopper is volatile. Just ask Andrew Moquin, who reopened his jewelry store early last month, after three months of lockdown.

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, were sharing things were eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

title: Financial Brokers Must Now Act in Your Best Interest. What Does That Mean?
description: The next time you shop around for financial advice, more investment professionals will be able to assure you that theyre acting in your best interest. But whats really in your best interest is understanding precisely what that means.

title: Spend More on Society and Get More for Yourself
description: As the mounting death toll and job losses from the coronavirus have made clear, the United States would be in far better shape if it had invested more heavily in public health, as well as in the countrys aging infrastructure and porous social safety net.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Park Slope, on the Lower East Side and in Parkchester.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties are four-bedroom homes in Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Lawrence, N.J.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Government Executes Second Federal Death Row Prisoner in a Week
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department executed a 68-year-old man on Thursday for the gruesome murder in 1998 of a teenage girl, the second time this week the federal government has carried out capital punishment after a 17-year hiatus.

title: Unfamiliar Territory for Indian Bridal Industry
description: When the Indian fashion designer Sabyasachi Mukherjee debuted his fine jewelry at Bergdorf Goodman in January, he had big plans for promoting his collection. But the coronavirus outbreak forced him and the luxury department-store chain to make some big adjustments.

title: British Vogue Editor Says the Magazines Security Racially Profiled Him
description: The editor of British Vogue, Edward Enninful, said he was racially profiled after being told by a security guard to use the loading bay as he entered the magazines offices in London this week.

title: In Coronavirus Vaccine Race, China Strays From the Official Paths
description: The offer to employees at the state-owned oil giant was compelling: Be among the first in China to take a coronavirus vaccine.

title: Retail economists worry that rise in sales could be fleeting.
description: Economists see both hopeful and worrying signs about the health of the American consumer in Thursdays retail sales figures.

title: The Most Popular Listings of June
description: The most viewed listings on The New York Timess Find a Home site in June included a massive gentlemans farm in Connecticut, a resort on an Australian island and homes in New Jersey, New York and Ontario, Canada.

title: Coronavirus Drug and Treatment Tracker
description: An updated list of potential treatments for Covid-19.

title: Russia Is Trying to Steal Virus Vaccine Data, Western Nations Say
description: WASHINGTON  Russian hackers are attempting to steal coronavirus vaccine research, the American, British and Canadian governments said Thursday, accusing the Kremlin of opening a new front in its spy battles with the West amid the worldwide competition to contain the pandemic.

title: Biden Banks $242 Million as Big-Name Donors Write Huge Checks
description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. raised tens of millions of dollars in the last three months from major donors who gave more than $100,000, relying on some of the Democratic Partys deepest pockets to sharply shrink President Trumps financial advantage, according to new federal filings.

title: Now That Studio Ghibli Is Streaming on HBO Max, Where Do You Start?
description: For decades, Studio Ghibli has broken mold after mold of what we expect films for kids to be.

title: Finally, Some Good News (Carved From 90 Pounds of Butter)
description: Fear not, Minnesotans.

title: Florida, Georgia and California show a rise in jobless claims.
description: In some of the states hardest hit by the resurgence in the coronavirus, initial jobless claims jumped last week, a sign of the renewed economic toll wrought by the pandemic.

title: How a Struggling Company Won $1.6 Billion to Make a Coronavirus Vaccine
description: In late February, as the coronavirus spread around the world, Dr. Richard Hatchett, the head of an international nonprofit that gives money to vaccine developers, got on an important call to discuss vaccine candidates after his plane touched down at Londons Heathrow Airport.

title: Solitary leisure is one bright spot on the retail landscape.
description: Some of the bright spots in spending have included areas like home improvement and sporting goods and bookstores. The retail sales data for June showed a 27 percent jump in the category of sporting goods, hobby, musical instruments and bookstores, which rose even compared to June 2019, and followed a surge in May.

title: The Sunlit Night Review: A Trip to the Arctic to Find Her Muse
description: There are many reasons Jenny Slate is a distinctive performer  her voice, her balance of liveliness and calm  but one of her more practical gifts onscreen is that she nails millennial professional anxiety, acting in the registers between deference, exhaustion and indifference. In the travelogue drama The Sunlit Night, she plays Frances, an artist who takes on a summer apprenticeship in remote Norway.

title: Leonardo Villar, Venerated Brazilian Actor, Dies at 96
description: Leonardo Villar, whose star turn as Donkey Jack in The Given Word (also known in English as Keeper of Promises) made him one of Brazils most revered actors and helped the film clinch the top prize at Cannes in 1962, died on July 3 in So Paulo. He was 96.

title: We Interrupt This Gloom to Offer  Hope
description: Just one in six Americans in a poll last month was proud of the state of the country, and about two out of three were actually fearful about it. So let me introduce a new thought: hope.

title: How Ultra-Black Fish Disappear in the Deepest Seas
description: Alexander Davis admits that he can be a glutton for punishment. He staked part of his Ph.D. on finding some of the worlds best-camouflaged fishes in the oceans deepest depths. These animals are so keen on not being found that theyve evolved the ability to absorb more than 99.9 percent of the light that hits their skin.

title: Pandemics Headache for Managers: Downs, Ups and  Now What?
description: Phil Tulkoffs family has owned a Baltimore condiment company for more than 90 years, and hes uneasy. Not because business at Tulkoff Food Products is bad  he lived through that this spring  but because it is suddenly good.

title: The eurozone economy is still fragile, E.C.B. president says.
description: The European economy hit bottom in April and began bouncing back in May and June, the eurozones top central banker said Thursday. But Christine Lagarde, the president of the European Central Bank, also warned that the economic recovery has been uneven and that the region has a long way to go to get back to normal.

title: Need a Drink? Make It Just One
description: A government panel may soon suggest that Americans limit their consumption of alcohol to just one drink per day. So what does that mean?

title: What Happens Now to All That Washington N.F.L. Merchandise?
description: Matt Pearson was born in Washington, D.C., in 1983, which means he is old enough to remember watching his hometown football team win their second Super Bowl in 1988. He remembers the smell of chips and beer, his parents screaming like crazy at the television, the teams record-breaking comeback and victory.

title: A Club of G.O.P. Political Heirs Push Back on Trump
