description: Hana Kimura, a professional wrestler in Japan, joined the cast of the hit reality show Terrace House in September because, as she said, she wanted to find a wonderful romance.

title: Hackers Tell the Story of the Twitter Attack From the Inside
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  A Twitter hacking scheme that targeted political, corporate and cultural elites this week began with a teasing message between two hackers late Tuesday on the online messaging platform Discord.

title: The Community That Covid-19 Built
description: The wagon on Jennifer Oiss front porch is a symbol of the coronaviruss silver lining. Its red and wooden, with black rubber wheels that once fell off, when Ms. Ois was towing her first child and a frozen turkey home from a store many years ago.

title: Picking Your Sunday Read
description: What kind of story do you want to listen to on a Sunday morning?

title: Newsom Outlines Reopening Guidelines for California Schools
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California announced new rules on Friday that would force many schools to start the year with virtual learning.

title: Emily Howell Warner, Who Broke a Sky-High Glass Ceiling, Dies at 80
description: Emily Howell Warner, a pilot who was credited with breaking a tropospheric glass ceiling in the 1970s as the first woman hired to command the flight deck of a commercial airliner in the United States, died on July 3 in a nursing home in Littleton, Colo. She was 80.

title: Newsom Order Would Keep Most California Schools Online
description: LOS ANGELES  Responding to soaring coronavirus infections and growing concern from teachers, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California announced new rules on Friday that would force many of the states districts to teach remotely when school starts next month.

title: Delta tells its pilots: Take a 15 percent pay cut and keep your jobs.
description: Delta Air Lines has told pilots it will not furlough them for a year if they accept a 15 percent cut to guaranteed pay, according a memo sent to staff on Friday.Our approach is to spread the work of a smaller airline among all our pilots to preserve all jobs  that would be unheard of in our history, John Laughter, senior vice president of flight operations, said in the memo, which was reviewed by The New York Times.

title: Prosecutors Drop Felony Charges Against 87 Breonna Taylor Protesters in Kentucky
description: Prosecutors have dropped felony charges against 87 protesters who peacefully gathered this week outside the Kentucky attorney generals home to demand charges against the police officers responsible for the death of Breonna Taylor.

title: Watchdog Faults Medicare Agencys Use of Communications Contractors
description: WASHINGTON  The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services violated federal contracting rules when its leaders misused communications consultants to burnish the image of the agency and its chief, Seema Verma, according to the Department of Health and Human Servicess inspector general.

title: Portland, Masks, Captain Tom: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Flossie Wong-Staal, Who Unlocked Mystery of H.I.V., Dies at 73
description: Flossie Wong-Staal, a molecular biologist who helped establish H.I.V. as the cause of AIDS, revealed the viruss inner-workings by cloning it and then laid the foundation for treatments, died on July 8 in San Diego. She was 73.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The United States continues to set daily infection records, with hospitalization and death rates on the rise  and Americans still cant stop fighting about masks.

title: Fighting Discrimination, a French Woman Becomes a Champion of Men
description: PARIS  Standing on a truck, her fist clenched high and her back turned to a row of police vans, Assa Traor galvanized the crowd before her.

title: Pence Attacks Biden at Wisconsin Campaign Event: You Wont Be Safe in Joe Bidens America
description: At a campaign stop in Ripon, Wis., Vice President Mike Pence on Friday suggested that a Biden presidency would fundamentally alter the fabric of the country.

title: Ex-Federal Reserve Chairs Urge More Economic Relief From Congress
description: Two former Federal Reserve chairs, Janet L. Yellen and Ben S. Bernanke, pushed for further economic relief from lawmakers, adding that it would take years before unemployment was back to pre-pandemic levels.

title: For Third Time This Week, the Federal Government Carries Out an Execution
description: WASHINGTON  A 52-year-old man was put to death on Friday for the 1993 murders of five people, the third federal execution this week after a 17-year hiatus of federal capital punishment.

title: The Justice Departments Shameful Rush to Federal Executions
description: Early on Tuesday morning, while much of the country was still asleep, the federal government executed its first death-row prisoner in 17 years. We are among the lawyers who represented the prisoner who was killed, Daniel Lee.

title: The Tenacity of the Franco-American Ideal
description: PARIS  Perhaps the root of the mutual fascination that binds France and the United States is that each sees itself as an idea, a model of some kind for the rest of the world. This is an immodest but tenacious notion, bound up with the founding articles and myths of both republics. No other countries make such claims for the universality of their virtue.

title: 10 Fingers, 2 Feet and 5,000 Pipes, Breathing Life Into the Present
description: The last time I was in a church was the week before New York Citys coronavirus lockdown, nearly five months and a lifetime ago.

title: Bidens School Plan Draws Clear Contrast With Trumps
description: Follow our live coverage of the 2020 election between Joe Biden and President Trump.

title: While Virus Surges, Georgia Governor Sues Atlanta Mayor to Block Mask Rules
description: Throughout the season of the pandemic, governors and local leaders have bickered, at times fiercely, over the best way to safeguard the public health. But perhaps no place has seen these disputes break out into hostility quite like Georgia this week, which culminated in the governor filing a lawsuit against the mayor of the states capital and economic engine.

title: The Legal System Should Not Be a Tool for Bullies
description: The New York State Legislature has before it an important bill that would discourage abusive lawsuits filed with the sole purpose of silencing critics. Known as SLAPPs, for strategic lawsuits against public participation, the suits are deliberate misuses of the legal system intended to choke off free speech.

title: Jane Walentas, Who Planted a Carousel in Dumbo, Dies at 76
description: Jane Walentas, an artist who spent more than 20 years restoring a century-old carousel as a gift to the Brooklyn waterfront neighborhood that she helped her husband, David Walentas, develop, died on July 5 at her home in Southampton, N.Y. She was 76.

title: Treacherous Times for Dr. Fauci in the Sacred Cow Business
description: WASHINGTON  For a while there, it looked possible that Dr. Anthony S. Fauci  the nations top infectious disease expert and a Washington sacred cow if there ever was one  might come away from the Trump White House unscathed. He was viewed as bipartisan (served six presidents!) and a savvy truth-teller able to skirt the reputational contagions that can accompany prolonged exposure to President Trump.

title: Washington N.F.L. Harassment Report Shocked Many, but Not Women
description: After news broke Thursday that there were accusations of rampant sexual harassment within the Washington N.F.L. franchise, several colleagues at womens organizations hopped on their group chat.

title: Gabriella Tucci, 90, Dies; Italian Soprano and Met Opera Mainstay
description: Gabriella Tucci, an Italian soprano whose richly expressive voice and beguiling stage presence made her a mainstay at major international houses  including, for 13 consecutive seasons, the Metropolitan Opera  died on July 9 in Rome. She was 90.

title: F.B.I. Agent in Russia Inquiry Saw Basis in Early 2017 to Doubt Dossier
description: WASHINGTON  A top F.B.I. agent recognized by February 2017 that a now notorious dossier of claims about purported Trump-Russia ties had credibility problems, but the Justice Department continued to rely on it as part of its basis to renew permission to wiretap a former Trump campaign adviser, documents released on Friday showed.

title: Tiger Woods, Injured Grinder, Makes Cut at the Memorial
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  When he was younger, Tiger Woods looked forward to getting older.

title: Were the Actions of Federal Agents in Portland Legal?
description: The Department of Homeland Securitys deployment of federal agents to Portland, Ore., has shown the broad legal authority an agency created to protect the United States from national security threats has to crack down on American citizens.

title: Utility Company Gave Jobs to Allies of Top Illinois Democrat, Prosecutors Say
description: When it came to a scheme to try to influence the speaker of the Illinois House, a politician so deft and powerful that he is known as the Velvet Hammer, a lobbyist had some plain advice for his client, Commonwealth Edison, the states largest electric utility, prosecutors say.

title: Cheeky
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  I blame the dog days for dulling my senses, but this collaboration between John Guzzetta and Michael Hawkins (their seventh for The Times, by my count) required me to take a second, closer look to fully appreciate the nuances. Its not extremely hard for a Saturday, and theres a breezy quality about it that made my brain coast a little bit, but theres a lot of riffing going on throughout that makes for a really cool and clever grid.

title: American Crime and the Baltimore Model
description: In 2014, there were 211 homicides in the city of Baltimore. The following year, there were 342, an astonishing increase of 62 percent. The murder rate has barely budged since.

title: 50 Nights of Unrest in Portland
description: Thursday night marked the 50th consecutive night of demonstrations in Portland, Ore. The protests began after the killing of George Floyd  tens of thousands of people took to the streets to protest police violence and racial injustice. Since then, the protests have grown smaller, but clashes between law enforcement officers and protesters have escalated on July 12, videos circulated of a federal officer shooting a protester in the head with a nonlethal munition, resulting in a skull fracture. Coverage of the unrest has caught the attention of President Trump, who vowed to dominate the protesters with federal law enforcement officers.

title: John Lewis, Towering Figure of Civil Rights Era, Dies at 80
description: Representative John Lewis, a son of sharecroppers and an apostle of nonviolence who was bloodied at Selma and across the Jim Crow South in the historic struggle for racial equality, and who then carried a mantle of moral authority into Congress, died on Friday. He was 80.

title: John Lewis Risked His Life for Justice
description: Representative John Lewis, who died Friday at age 80, will be remembered as a principal hero of the blood-drenched era not so long ago when Black people in the South were being shot, blown up or driven from their homes for seeking basic human rights. The moral authority Mr. Lewis exercised in the House of Representatives  while representing Georgias Fifth Congressional District for more than 30 years  found its headwaters in the aggressive yet self-sacrificial style of protests that he and his compatriots in the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee deployed in the early 1960s as part of the campaign that overthrew Southern apartheid.

title: Quotation of the Day: To Citys Alarm, Federal Officers Police Portland
description: I feel like Im being hunted for no reason.

title: Corrections: July 18, 2020
description: An article on Sunday about the relationship between China and Iran misstated the location of the academic institution where an Iranian energy researcher is based. The researcher, Ali Gholizadeh, is at the University of Science and Technology of China in Hefei, not in Beijing.

title: Praise for John Lewis Pours in From Nations Political Elite
description: WASHINGTON  A giant. A legendary leader. A civil rights icon. A human saint.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Father Soldier Son and the Dance on Camera Festival
description: FATHER SOLDIER SON Stream on Netflix. This documentary, which was directed by the New York Times journalists Catrin Einhorn and Leslye Davis, has been 10 years in the making. Though much has been reported about the hardships some soldiers and their families face upon returning home from combat, this film focuses on one family and chronicles its changing dynamic. It begins in 2010, when Master Sgt. Brian Eisch, a single father, leaves two young sons for a yearlong deployment in Afghanistan. He then returns home following a serious injury, which requires his leg to be amputated below the knee. His experience at war and back at home  where he not only struggles physically, but with a loss of identity  ultimately affects what his sons hope for their own futures. Life, in Father Soldier Son does not move in a circle," Jessica Kiang wrote in her review for The New York Times, but in an incrementally decaying orbit around the values that, in making us what we are, also keep us from being anything else."

title: How PG&E Is Racing to Improve Safety as Fire Season Approaches
description: NAPA, Calif.  Atop an electrical pole overlooking grapevines, Pacific Gas & Electric recently installed a piece of equipment that will allow it to quickly turn off power to this part of Californias wine country when conditions for a wildfire are just right.

title: Long Waits for U.K. Hospital Treatment as N.H.S. Fights Coronavirus
description: LONDON  After nine months of waiting for surgery, Ruth Fawcetts knee muscles wasted away, causing her joint to come loose in its socket and leaving her unable to walk without assistance.

title: Lost and Now Found, Leeds Returns to the Premier League
description: LEEDS, England  On the touchline, a member of the coaching staff had leapt into the arms of the defender Stuart Dallas, and was hanging onto him for dear life. Andrea Radrizzani, the team owner, was standing by the tunnel, embracing every player who approached him. In the stands, Victor Orta, the technical director, was pumping his arms and screaming into the sky.

title: Hardcore Cyclists Head for the Hills  Mexico Citys
description: Among Mexico Citys bicycling enthusiasts, the mountain road that twists up through the canyon in Los Dinamos National Park on the outer edge of the city is a rite of passage.

title: Battle in the Himalayas
description: China and India are locked in a tense, deadly struggle for advantage on their disputed mountain border.

title: The Horror Novel Lurking in Your Busy Online Life
description: In early April, at the height of the pandemic lockdown, Gianpiero Petriglieri, an Italian business professor, suggested on Twitter that being forced to conduct much of our lives online was making us sick. The constant video calls and Zoom meetings were draining us because they go against our brains need for boundaries: here versus not here. Its easier being in each others presence, or in each others absence, he wrote, than in the constant presence of each others absence.

title: Trump Promotes Caricature of What Conservatives Want
description: Standing in the White House colonnade this week, President Trump told an interviewer that hes comfortable with freedom of speech extending to the Confederate flag.

title: Exploring Their Own Paths Together
description: Because marriage is an ever-evolving experience, we constantly shift, change and, in some cases, start over. In Its No Secret, couples share thoughts about commitment and tell us what they have learned, revealing their secret to making it work. (Answers are edited for context and space.)

title: Race Takes Center Stage as Rashida Tlaib Faces Primary Challenge
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich.  Representative Rashida Tlaib, one of Congresss most famous members, is perhaps best known for her membership in the progressive group known as the squad and her strident attacks on President Trump.

title: Sing Figaros Aria and Diagram Your Garden
description: Here is a sampling of the weeks events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.

title: Why Trumps Attacks on John Roberts Arent Working With Some Conservatives
description: LA PORTE, Ind.  Mitch Feikes is one of many conservatives who disagreed with some of Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.s recent decisions, including striking down a restrictive Louisiana abortion law and ruling against the White House in its effort to undo an Obama-era immigration program.

title: What Is a Travel Columnists Role When Travel Stops?
description: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.

title: For Families of 9/11 Victims, Virus Further Slows the Pace of Justice
description: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

title: Mistrust of a Coronavirus Vaccine Could Imperil Widespread Immunity
description: Almost daily, President Trump and leaders worldwide say they are racing to develop a coronavirus vaccine, in perhaps the most urgent mission in the history of medical science. But the repeated assurances of near-miraculous speed are exacerbating a problem that has largely been overlooked and one that public health experts say must be addressed now: persuading people to actually get the shot.

title: A Covid-19 Lesson: Some Seriously Ill Patients Can Be Treated at Home
description: Joan Murray had been home with Covid-19 for about a week when she ran into trouble. She had a fever of 103 degrees and chills that sent shivers up and down her spine. Her oxygen levels were dropping, and the tightness in her chest felt as if somebody had bound up my lungs with string.

title: He Kept a Communitys Bears in Check, but He Wont Anymore
description: You cant teach a misbehaving black bear a lesson through a Zoom conference call.

title: Fire Hits Cathedral in French City of Nantes
description: A fire broke out inside the cathedral of the western French city of Nantes in the early hours of Saturday, but the authorities quickly said there was no comparison with the blaze that engulfed Notre-Dame in Paris last year, despite ominous images of flames and smoke coming from the building.

title: Someone Tore Down a Union Army Statue in Saratoga Springs. Why?
description: Early on Thursday morning, the police in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., found a cast iron and zinc statue torn down from its stone pedestal in Congress Park and scattered in pieces on the grass.

title: Our Role Is to Reduce Their Grief
description: THE DESERT WEST OF NAJAF  There are no signs to signal the way to the New Valley of Peace, or, as the Iraqis call it, the Corona cemetery. But its not hard to find: Just follow the cars. Its the only place they are headed on the rough desert road.

title: Trump Administration Aims to Block New Funding for Coronavirus Testing and Tracing
description: Follow our live updates of coronavirus cases and deaths globally.

title: China Is Dismantling the Empire of a Vanished Tycoon
description: HONG KONG  Xiao Jianhua was once a trusted financier to Chinas ruling elite who came to represent an era of unbridled capitalism.

title: This Border Town Was on the Rise. Then the Pandemic Hit.
description: BLAINE, Wash.  Over the past couple of years, Mike Hill poured more than $3.5 million into renovating his Chevron gas station and opening a Starbucks next door. People from British Columbia were crossing the border in droves to buy cheap gas and milk in Blaine, Wash. It seemed like a slam dunk investment.

title: How to Kill a Vampire: Not With This Kit, Apparently
description: Vampires, beware.

title: Can I Stop Paying for Amenities That Closed Because of the Pandemic?
description: Q: The gym, billiards room and childrens playroom in our apartment building have been closed for months, with no prospect of reopening anytime soon. We paid a premium for this apartment partly because of the amenity package. Now, we cant use it. Should we get a credit for loss of services?

title: Finally Write That Short Story
description: Though some people have knocked out an entire short story in a single sitting, its more realistic to see writing a story not as an inspiration-fueled creative binge but as a multiweek project. Its one youre a lot likelier to finish if, rather than waiting for the muse, you create the possibility for inspiration by planning a time and setting up the circumstances that will allow you to write regularly. It also should be fun! The act of constructing plots, developing characters and creating dialogue can be challenging, even frustrating, but I never find it boring, and it just might allow you to escape from your daily life at the same time that you access the most imaginative parts of your own brain.

title: As Seasonal Rains Fall, Dispute Over Nile Dam Rushes Toward a Reckoning
description: CAIRO  Every day now, seasonal rain pounds the lush highlands of northern Ethiopia, sending cascades of water into the Blue Nile, the twisting tributary of perhaps Africas most fabled river.

title: The Crispiest Tofu Sandwich
description: The weeks most popular dishes include Superiority Burgers fried tofu sandwich (above), David Taniss black bean burger with a fried egg and Genevieve Kos crispy rice with shrimp, bacon and corn. Find more recipes in the collection below.

title: Federal Officers Deployed in Portland Didnt Have Proper Training, D.H.S. Memo Said
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  The federal agents facing a growing backlash for their militarized approach to weeks of unrest in Portland were not specifically trained in riot control or mass demonstrations, an internal Department of Homeland Security memo warned this week.

title: Nicaraguas Ruling Sandinistas Fall Victim to Covid-19, Highlighting the Diseases Spread
description: A string of recent deaths across Nicaragua  including mayors, judges, police officials, sports figures, university rectors and government bureaucrats  is pointing to the chilling reality that the coronavirus is devastating this Central American country, although the government is not publicly acknowledging it.

title: Republicans Keep Flunking Microbe Economics
description: Governor Ron DeSantis of Florida said something remarkably stupid the other day. I know, I know: its probably harder to find a day on which DeSantis didnt say something stupid than a day on which he did. But this particular piece of thickheadedness, Id argue, helps us understand why Americas response to the coronavirus has been so disastrous compared with other wealthy nations.

title: A More Liberal Supreme Court? Not When It Comes to Voting Rights
description: For the fourth time since April, the Supreme Court this week made it harder for Americans to vote. The ruling, Justice Sonia Sotomayor wrote in dissent, was part of a trend of condoning disfranchisement.

title: Officer Who Pressed His Knee on George Floyds Neck Drew Scrutiny Long Before
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The four teenagers drove around playing a game of Nerf Gun Assassin on a May evening before graduation in 2013. One of them randomly fired an orange dart out the window.

title: London Police Urged to Apologize After Officer Knelt on Mans Neck
description: LONDON  The lawyer for a Black man who repeatedly asked a white officer to get off my neck as he was pinned to the sidewalk during an arrest in London told a court on Saturday that the encounter echoed the treatment of George Floyd in the United States and called for a police apology.

title: The Doctor Versus the Denier
description: WASHINGTON  Never mind Johnny Depp and Amber Heard.

title: I Wont Return to the Classroom, and You Shouldnt Ask Me To
description: SEDRO-WOOLLEY, Wash.  Every day when I walk into work as a public-school teacher, I am prepared to take a bullet to save a child. In the age of school shootings, thats what the job requires. But asking me to return to the classroom amid a pandemic and expose myself and my family to Covid-19 is like asking me to take that bullet home to my own family.

title: Learning to Heal, With a Little Fur Machine
description: Everyone knows youre not supposed to judge a book by its cover, but many of us do it anyway. In the case of Joan Bauers 14th novel, RAISING LUMIE (Viking, 288 pp., $16.99; ages 10 to 13), you might see the jacket photograph of a fuzzy yellow Labrador retriever puppy and assume youre in for a cozy, heartwarming tale. You would be wrong. Sort of.

title: Creating a More Equitable Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Family-Friendly Movies Made by Diverse Filmmakers
description: For parents trying to figure out how to talk to their children about racism, film can be a useful tool for generating empathy. But many family-friendly movies with diverse casts are told from a white perspective, for a white audience. That can rob people of color of their turns as the hero, nullifying their voices. And the stories are usually about racism, presenting the issue as a problem to be solved, wrapping up in a neat resolution.

title: Breathe Better With These Nine Exercises
description: Breathe. We do it roughly 25,000 times a day, but until recently few of us gave much thought to this automatic bodily function.

title: Frans Nieuwendam, Who Knew Style and Had It, Dies at 60
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Defying Kremlin, Protesters Stage Biggest Rally Yet in Russian Far East
description: MOSCOW  Ignoring pleas from the Kremlin for calm after more than a week of unrest, protesters in the Russian Far East on Saturday staged their biggest display of defiance yet, with tens of thousands of people pouring into the streets to protest the arrest of a popular regional governor.

title: Travel The World With Your Ears
description: At this point in the summer  and the pandemic  the desire to escape to a place far away might be overwhelming. Even with so many borders closed, podcasts can transport you elsewhere, making them a good alternative to real, out-of-the-house travel. Heres a collection of immersive audio experiences that are almost as immersive as exploring the great wide world out there.

title: The First Time John Lewis and I Integrated the Buses
description: John Lewis, the civil rights icon, died on Friday. He had announced in December that he had Stage 4 pancreatic cancer.

title: Inside Trumps Failure: The Rush to Abandon Leadership Role on the Virus
description: Follow our live coverage of the 2020 election between Joe Biden and President Trump.

title: Inside the Failure: 5 Takeaways on Trumps Effort to Shift Responsibility
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump and his top aides decided to shift primary responsibility for the coronavirus response to the states during a critical period of weeks in mid-April, eagerly seizing on overly optimistic predictions that the pandemic was fading so the president could reopen the economy and focus on his re-election, a New York Times investigation found.

title: Trump Weighs In on the Death of John Lewis, One of His Most Vocal Critics
description: WASHINGTON  The Republican governor of Georgia said that the country will never be the same without Representative John Lewis, who died Friday at age 80. The Democratic speaker of the house called Mr. Lewis a titan of the civil rights movement. The House minority leader said that Mr. Lewis never stopped working to improve the lives of others.

title: Brigid Berlin, Socialite Who Joined Warhols World, Dies at 80
description: Here is one way to make a first impression.

title: Doing Schoolwork in the Parking Lot Is Not a Solution
description: When Autumn Lee, a pre-med junior at the University of New Mexico, needs to download lectures or class assignments, she hops in her car and drives 45 minutes to the McDonalds nearest to her town of Sanders, Ariz., to connect to reliable Wi-Fi from her car. After the university sent students home because of the coronavirus pandemic, Ms. Lee grew frustrated with what she said is expensive and data-restricted internet service in Sanders, an unincorporated village of fewer than 1,000 people in eastern Arizona. Relying on her smartphone data plan wasnt much of an alternative. It took one or two hours to watch a 20-minute lecture, she said. I just got so frustrated, I figured there had to be another way. So she made the 40-mile trek several times each week  and shell likely have to keep doing it now that the school has canceled nearly all in-person classes for the fall.

title: Older Children Spread the Coronavirus Just as Much as Adults, Large Study Finds
description: In the heated debate over reopening schools, one burning question has been whether and how efficiently children can spread the virus to others.

title: The Real White Fragility
description: In 2001, when I was still attending college, David Brooks wrote an essay for The Atlantic called The Organization Kid, in which he spent a lot of time with young Ivy Leaguers and came away struck by their basic existential contentment. Instead of campus rebels, they were rsum builders and accomplishment collectors and apple polishers, distinguished by their serenity, their faux-adult professionalism, their politesse.

title: They Didnt Just Love Him. They Knew Him. Young Atlanta Activists Mourn John Lewis.
description: ATLANTA  By the time the Rev. James Woodall came to know John Lewis, Mr. Lewis was already a longtime congressman and a towering figure in the civil rights movement, one whose legacy loomed large over Atlanta.

title: Oakland Will Pay $32.7 Million to Settle Ghost Ship Fire Lawsuits
description: The city of Oakland, Calif., has agreed to pay nearly $33 million to settle lawsuits filed on behalf of the victims of a fire that killed 36 people in a two-story converted warehouse in 2016.

title: Remembering John Lewis, a Civil Rights Icon
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Rules of Dating
description: Dating is a complicated and often clumsy dance even in the best of times. Add in mask-wearing directives, social distancing and fear of a highly contagious virus for which there is no cure, and you get well, an awful lot of people going out and doing some version of it anyway. A survey conducted by Everlywell  a company that makes at-home health tests  found that nearly one in four Americans ages 20 to 31 broke quarantine to have sexual contact with someone in April, when stay-at-home orders were at their peak.

title: Doubles Play
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  I often marvel at the number of clean theme entries a deft constructor comes up with for a Sunday grid (especially when I cant come up with a single one, as often happens). When I figured out the trick today, I went in the opposite direction and briefly imagined how fun a giant mega-puzzle would be, with 26 examples, if that would even be possible. Itd certainly be over the top, maybe even in excess!

title: Blue Jays Cant Play Games in Canada Because of Pandemic
description: Major League Baseballs plan to use all 30 home ballparks for a shortened, 60-game season met an immovable obstacle on Saturday: the Canadian government. The Toronto Blue Jays, the only team in the league that is based outside the United States, will not be allowed to stage home games during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: From the Archive: Forgiving George Wallace
description: John Lewis wrote in a 1998 Op-Ed about the best way to remember the former governor of Alabama.

title: 2 Republican Senators Post Photos of Elijah Cummings in John Lewis Tributes
description: Like thousands of other Americans, Senators Marco Rubio and Dan Sullivan took to social media on Saturday to mourn the death of Representative John Lewis, a venerated figure of the civil rights movement.

title: Who Were the Freedom Riders?
description: Representative John Lewis, who died on Friday at 80, was an imposing figure in American politics and the civil rights movement. But his legacy of confronting racism directly, while never swaying from his commitment to nonviolence, started long before he became a national figure.

title: Amid a Pandemic, Supporters Hope John Lewis Can Still Lie in State in the Capitol
description: When Representative Elijah E. Cummings became the first Black lawmaker to lie in state in the Capitol last fall, the public poured into Statuary Hall, a choir from Morgan State University sang and admirers cried and hugged.

title: Trump Administration Balks at Funding for Testing and C.D.C. in Virus Relief Bill
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration has balked at providing billions of dollars to fund coronavirus testing and shore up federal health agencies as the virus surges across the country, complicating efforts to reach agreement on the next round of pandemic aid.

title: Death of John Lewis Fuels Movement to Rename Edmund Pettus Bridge
description: The death of Representative John Lewis on Friday has renewed interest in a campaign to rename the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala., the site of a turning point in the fight for civil rights.

title: 3 Dead After Glacier Tour Bus Rolls Over in Canadian Rockies
description: OTTAWA  A popular tourist outing in the Rocky Mountains in Alberta turned into a scene of chaos after a glacier tour bus rolled on Saturday afternoon, killing three passengers and injuring 24 others on board, according to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

title: Quotation of the Day: Civil Rights Icon Turned Conscience of Congress
description: This feels and looks so different. It is so much more massive and all inclusive. There will be no turning back.

title: Southern Europe Opens Its Doors to Tourists. Not Many Are Coming.
description: ADEJE, Spain  Music blared from a beachfront cafe along the normally bustling southwestern coast of Tenerife, the largest of Spains Canary Islands. But several tables sat empty, a month after a Covid-19 lockdown had ended, and the doors to many resorts remained shut.

title: India Rounds Up Critics Under Shadow of Virus Crisis, Activists Say
description: NEW DELHI  After spending several anxious days in prison, Natasha Narwal, a student activist accused of rioting by the New Delhi police, thought her ordeal was nearing an end.

title: Corrections: July 19, 2020
description: An article last Sunday about artists in Newark amid the pandemic and protests misstated the name of a museum. It is the Newark Museum of Art, not the Newark Museum.

title: Whats on TV Sunday: The Last Dance and United Shades of America
description: THE LAST DANCE Stream on Netflix. After debuting on ESPN in May, all 10 hours of this Michael Jordan documentary are available to stream. The series, which was produced by ESPN Films, Netflix and Jordan himself, chronicles the athletes legacy and time with the Chicago Bulls, including the teams storied 1998 season. As Wesley Morris wrote in his Critics Notebook for The New York Times, The series is this ocean of archival game clips, dunk montages, smack talk, mea culpas, cigar smoking, backstabbing, frontstabbing, manfully restrained tears, endorsements of the triangle offense and interviews with anybody who even blinked at the N.B.A. from 1984 to 1998.

title: They Came From Moose Jaw and Kapuskasing. They Were the New York Rangers.
description: The pandemic has forced the N.H.L. to finish its season at two hubs in Canada, Edmonton and Toronto.

title: Roger Stone Denies Using Racial Slur on Radio Show
description: Roger Stone, the political operative who was spared a prison sentence this month by his friend President Trump, denied on Sunday that he had uttered a racial slur on a radio show the night before, calling the accusation a smear while also contending the word was not offensive.

title: One Day While I Was Shopping at Macys, I Lost Track of the Time
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Tokyo Olympics Will Open a Year From Now. Maybe.
description: A year from now, the world will begin to gather in Japan to celebrate the opening of the Tokyo Olympics, which were originally supposed to begin this week.

title: Demagogue Remembers a Vintage American Bully
description: Its not often that a mans name becomes an ism, Larry Tye writes in his new biography of Joseph McCarthy, the senator from Wisconsin whose crusade against Communism ensured that his name would endure as a synonym for reckless accusation, guilt by association, fear-mongering and political double-dealing. Tye writes in his preface that while the book focuses on McCarthys life, its also about a particularly American strain of demagogy that has existed from the countrys earliest days to Huey Long to George Wallace to the astonishing ascension of President Donald J. Trump. Below, Tye discusses McCarthys fanaticism, his enablers, his military experience and more.

title: Why Intellectuals Support Dictators
description: TWILIGHT OF DEMOCRACYThe Seductive Lure of AuthoritarianismBy Anne Applebaum

title: How Buying Beans Became a Political Statement
description: For years, the Goya brand was synonymous with the Latino-American dream. The sheer number of products that lined the grocery store aisles  from refried pinto beans to sazn con azafran seasoning  spoke to the growing number of Hispanic immigrants who bought them. Goya, the nations largest Hispanic food company, has sponsored Dominican art shows, mariachi contests and soccer programs.

title: During Coronavirus Lockdowns, Some Doctors Wondered: Where Are the Preemies?
description: This spring, as countries around the world told people to stay home to slow the spread of the coronavirus, doctors in neonatal intensive care units were noticing something strange: Premature births were falling, in some cases drastically.

description: Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.

description: Good morning. A financial tip: When someone on the internet asks for Bitcoin and promises double your money back, its probably a lie. Heres what else you need to know in business and tech news for the week ahead.

description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

title: Dorothy Parkers Ashes Could Be Moved. Again.
description: When the N.A.A.C.P. moves its headquarters from Baltimore to Washington in the coming years, theres a small object from a backyard garden it doesnt plan to take along: the ashes of the New York writer and critic Dorothy Parker.

title: Luther Price, Experimental Artist and Filmmaker, Dies at 58
description: Luther Price, a multimedia artist and prolific experimental filmmaker known for his haunting, often transgressive work  as well as for never revealing his real name  died on June 13 at his home in Revere, Mass. He was 58.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Good morning. Family meal is what restaurant people call the dinner served to the staff before service, which is the term they use to describe when the restaurant is open to customers. Family meals are generally made by a line cook, someone who works a particular station in the kitchen  the grill, say, or the stove. A line cook is not the restaurants chef, but answers to one or to the chefs lieutenant, who is known as a sous chef. This is all in keeping with the system by which the French first organized the professional kitchen: a brigade de cuisine.

title: With Tourists Gone, St. Patricks Cathedral Pleads for Help
description: St. Patricks Cathedral, one of the most famous churches in the United States, has long depended on tourists and office workers to fill its pews and its collection plates. But now that the coronavirus has left Midtown Manhattan largely deserted, it is facing a $4 million budget shortfall that may threaten its ability to pay its bills.

title: Clearly, the Virus Isnt the Only Problem
description: Theres a reason the U.S. is failing at containing Covid-19.

title: This 19th-Century Law Helps Shape Criminal Justice in Indian Country
description: There was something of a scramble, after the Supreme Court ruled in McGirt v. Oklahoma that much of Eastern Oklahoma was now officially Indian Country.

title: Start Looking, and Youll See Roads All Over the Bible
description: Once, my life was made of bread. I was the pastor of a dinner church where our worship took the form of a meal we cooked and ate together. Our church was filled not with pews, but with tables. Not with the heady smell of incense, but onions softening in olive oil and rosemary as the bread warmed in the oven.

title: India Offers Escape to Afghan Hindus and Sikhs Facing Attacks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Indian government said it will expedite visas and the possibility of long-term residency for Afghanistans tiny Hindu and Sikh minorities, shrunken by decades of persecution and decimated by attacks in recent years amid the Afghan war.

title: Renaming the Army Bases
description: To the Editor:

title: Showdown on Beach in Bulgaria Balloons Into Political Crisis
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria  Leaked photographs of the prime minister. A police raid on the presidents office. A business tycoons takeover of a public beach. A looming no-confidence vote in the government. And the largest street protests in seven years.

title: Trump Leans Into False Virus Claims in Combative Fox News Interview
description: WASHINGTON  An agitated President Trump offered a string of combative and often dubious assertions in an interview aired Sunday, defending his handling of the coronavirus with misleading evidence, attacking his own health experts, disputing polls showing him trailing in his re-election race and defending people who display the Confederate flag as victims of cancel culture.

title: As Trump Ignores Virus Crisis, Republicans Start to Break Ranks
description: Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.

title: The Met Opera Tries to Find Paying Customers in a Pandemic
description: After the coronavirus pandemic forced concert halls and opera houses to close this spring, online performances proliferated. The Metropolitan Opera began streaming nightly operas from its extensive video archive, and in April it presented an At-Home Gala, broadcast over smartphones from the homes of singers around the world.

title: Partyers Clash With German Police
description: BERLIN  Violence erupted overnight in Frankfurt between police officers and youths who have been partying in a central city square on weekends, with bars and clubs shuttered to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

title: More Resignations, but No Sign Yet of a Change in Gaming Culture
description: First, a popular esports tournament was canceled. Next, top gaming studio executives stepped down. Then, a prominent talent management agency for video game streamers laid off its employees and closed.

title: Mars Mission From United Arab Emirates Embarks on 7-Month Journey
description: Youll be hearing a lot about Mars in the weeks to come this summer. Three missions are launching toward the red planet, taking advantage of the way Earth and its neighbor get closer every 26 months or so, allowing a relatively short trip between the two worlds. If they launch successfully, the spacecraft will arrive at Mars early next year.

title: To Buy This Basquiat, Swipe Right
description: Testing the notion that blue-chip art can be sold with a swipe, the former Christies executive Loic Gouzer on Monday will use his new app as the auction block for a large drawing by Jean-Michel Basquiat that is estimated to sell for $8 million to $12 million.

title: Yankees and Mets Glad to Finally Face Someone Other Than Themselves
description: Major League Baseball during a pandemic looks like this: A masked hitter smashing a home run, a bottle of hand sanitizer hanging from an umpires waistband, cardboard cutouts of fans positioned in the seats behind home plate, artificial cheering used after plays that benefited the home team.

title: Krip-Hop Nation Showcases Rappers With Disabilities. Meet 5 of Our Favorites.
description: Since 2007, Krip-Hop Nation has been releasing mixtapes that showcase a worldwide network of hip-hop artists with disabilities. Here are five songs by members of its extended family that have appeared on them over the years.

title: Gordon Bower, Inventive Memory Researcher, Is Dead at 87
description: Gordon H. Bower, a research psychologist who spent more than half a century studying how the brain learns and remembers, as well as a host of related subjects, and who was among the leaders in his field, died on June 17 at his home in Stanford, Calif. He was 87.

title: Special Interests Mobilize to Get Piece of Next Virus Relief Package
description: WASHINGTON  Airlines, hotels and restaurants. Military contractors and banks. Even Broadway actors. These are just a few of the special interests already maneuvering to get a piece of the next coronavirus relief package about to be taken up by Congress.

title: Vulnerable Border Community Battles Virus on A Straight Up Trajectory
description: EDINBURG, Texas  On a sweltering day last week near the southern tip of Texas, where high rates of poverty and chronic illness have heightened the ferocity of the coronavirus, Dr. Renzo Arauco Brown made his rounds, checking on patients who were facing severe complications from the virus and barely hanging on to life.

title: REI Faces Staff Backlash Over Response to Covid-19 Cases
description: About 40 current and former employees of the outdoor equipment store REI in Grand Rapids, Mich., regularly communicate using the messaging app GroupMe. On July 6, they received a jarring note from a colleague.

title: Petition Urges Trader Joes to Get Rid of Racist Branding
description: Trader Joes is being urged to follow the example of other national food companies and rebrand products that critics say perpetuate racial stereotypes.

title: Wearing a Mask? It May Come From Chinas Controversial Labor Program
description: Our visual investigation reveals that several Chinese companies are using Uighur labor from a contentious government program to produce P.P.E. during the pandemic. We track some of that equipment to the U.S. and around the world.

title: China Is Using Uighur Labor to Produce Face Masks
description: As the coronavirus pandemic continues to drive demand for personal protective equipment, Chinese companies are rushing to manufacture the gear for domestic and global consumption. A New York Times visual investigation has found that some of those companies are using Uighur labor through a contentious government-sponsored program that experts say often puts people to work against their will.

title: Uighur Labor, Indian Arrests, Mars Mission: Your Monday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Trumps Hot-Button Fed Pick Faces Senate Committee Vote This Week
description: WASHINGTON  Judy Shelton, an unorthodox economist who was an adviser to President Trumps 2016 campaign, could move one step closer to a seat on the Federal Reserves Board of Governors this week.

title: Testing Backlogs May Cloud the True Spread of the Coronavirus
description: As demand for coronavirus testing surges around the nation, laboratories that process samples are again experiencing backlogs that have left anxious patients and their doctors waiting days sometimes a week or morefor results.

title: Nakotah LaRance, Acclaimed Native American Hoop Dancer, Dies at 30
description: Nakotah LaRance, a nationally acclaimed Hopi-Tewa hoop dancer who performed with Cirque du Soleil, died on July 12 near the Ohkay Owingeh Pueblo in New Mexico. He was 30.

title: Brazil Health Workers May Have Spread Coronavirus to Indigenous People
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The telltale symptoms began in late May, about a week after government medical workers made a routine visit to the Kanamari Indigenous community in a remote part of the Amazon: Elderly members of the group were struggling to breathe.

title: Amid a Deadly Virus and Crippled Economy, One Form of Aid Has Proved Reliable: Food Stamps
description: WASHINGTON  More than six million people enrolled in food stamps in the first three months of the coronavirus pandemic, an unprecedented expansion that is likely to continue as more jobless people deplete their savings and billions in unemployment aid expires this month.

title: Makeup of a Beach
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  I regret that I dont examine Monday puzzles too closely unless I have to postify them. Sure, were on the easiest day of the week in crossworld (making up for the challenges of Monday in, oh, every other aspect of our lives). That might mean fewer obscurities, a broader theme and much kinder crosses, but that doesnt mean there arent a lot of intricate folds and facets, and it doesnt mean that things are simple.

title: Which Country Will Triumph in the Post-Pandemic World?
description: Imagine a country, a major Western economic power, where the coronavirus arrived late but the government, instead of denying and delaying, acted early. It was ready with tests and contact tracing to flatten the curve swiftly and limited its death rate to orders of magnitude lower than that of any other major Western industrial nation. Containing the virus allowed for a brief and targeted lockdown, which helped limit unemployment to only 6 percent. Amid a shower of international praise, the countrys boringly predictable leader experienced a huge spike in popular approval, to 70 percent from 40 percent.

title: Where Is the Outrage?
description: It never ceases to amaze me how more people arent outraged, shocked and disgusted by Donald Trumps cruelty and malfeasance.

title: From Antifa to Mothers in Helmets, Diverse Elements Fuel Portland Protests
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Angela Foster started showing up in the early days of the protests in Portland as one of the novice activists standing off to the side with no gear to protect herself.

title: Top State Dept. Officials Enabled Misconduct by Pompeo, Whistle-Blower Said
description: WASHINGTON  A State Department employee who reported witnessing misconduct by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo as well as hearing numerous firsthand accounts of such behavior was blocked from further addressing the issue by top department officials who were protecting Mr. Pompeo, according to a newly public copy of the employees whistle-blower complaint.

title: An Ex-Times Reporter. An Ohio Wedding Provider. Covid Contrarians Go Viral.
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  If youve been following Gov. Mike DeWines coronavirus news conferences the way that New Yorkers follow Andrew Cuomos, you know Jack Windsor: Hes the reporter asking about creeping Marxism among contact tracers and suggesting that Ohio is double counting virus cases.

title: Tracy McGrady and Jermaine ONeal Have Been Talking. Theyre Starting a Sports Agency.
description: Tracy McGrady and Jermaine ONeal were high-profile teenagers who shared the same agent and sneaker brand in January 1998, when a mutual acquaintance suggested that they meet for a meal. They went to an Applebees restaurant in Portland, Ore.

title: Jon Rahms Two New Attributes: Composure and a Top Ranking
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  Sometimes a reputation is hard to shake. Just ask Jon Rahm, who for years was best known as a good golfer with a bad temper. But on Sunday evening, Rahm became renowned for being something else: the worlds new No. 1 ranked golfer.

title: Perry Mason Season 1, Episode 5 Recap: Leaps of Faith
description: It begins with the death of a lawyer and ends with the anointing of a new one. In between, this episode of Perry Mason covers a good deal of ground with nearly all of its characters, from the fed-up Black cop, Paul Drake, to the true-believer evangelist, Sister Alice, to the dogged legal secretary, Della Street, to the title character. Its the hour when Perry Mason stops being an origin story and starts becoming the first proper Perry Mason case.

title: Quotation of the Day: Allies of Trump Start to Break Ranks on Virus
description: The president got bored with it.

title: No Corrections: July 20, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 20, 2020.

title: Husband and Son of a Federal Judge Are Shot in New Jersey
description: A gunman shot the son of a federal judge at her home in New Jersey on Sunday, according to an official with knowledge of the situation. The Associated Press reported that he had died and that the judges husband also had been shot.

title: Whats on TV Monday: Ip Man 4: The Finale and Intervention
description: IP MAN 4: THE FINALE (2019) Stream on Netflix.; rent on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. In this martial arts film Ip Man (Donnie Yen), a real-life Wing Chun master who inspired the series, leaves Hong Kong for San Francisco, where he finds that the popularity of his student, Bruce Lee (Chan Kwok-Kwan Danny), has stirred tensions in the city. Some members of the local Chinese community are opposed to sharing martial arts secrets with non-Chinese students. The movies other antagonist is a bigoted Marine (Scott Adkins) who is promoting karate over kung fu. There is no mystery about who wins the movies final bout, Ben Kenigsberg wrote in his review for The New York Times, but it is never less than thrilling to watch Yens fluttering limbs in action.

title: Europe Said It Was Pandemic-Ready. Pride Was Its Downfall.
description: LONDON  Prof. Chris Whitty, Britains chief medical adviser, stood before an auditorium in a London museum two years ago cataloging deadly epidemics.

title: Businesses Are Supposed to Cut Debt in a Downturn. Why Not Now?
description: Since the 2008 global financial crisis, American corporations have taken advantage of historically low interest rates to gorge themselves on debt. Then came the pandemic and the sharpest economic downturn in history, which resulted in an odd solution for the companies that did all that borrowing: more debt.

title: A Stadium at Iowa State Says His Name: Jack Trice
description: Of the 130 universities that play major college football, only one  Iowa State  has a stadium named after an African-American person.

title: Jackie Robinsons Inner Struggle
description: It was Tuesday, Sept. 30, 1947  Game 1 of the World Series between the New York Yankees and the Brooklyn Dodgers  and Jack Roosevelt Jackie Robinson was making history. The Dodger first baseman was standing in a packed Yankee Stadium about to hear the national anthem. From a distance, the tableau can seem an inspiring inflection point: the first Black major leaguer in the 20th century playing in the first televised World Series. There I was, Robinson recalled in his 1972 memoir I Never Had It Made: An Autobiography, the Black grandson of a slave, the son of a Black sharecropper, part of a historic occasion, a symbolic hero to my people. So far, so good: The safe narrative of Robinson-as-stoic-hero is intact. The band struck up the national anthem, he wrote. It should have been a glorious moment for me as the stirring words  poured from the stands. Yet if we see the scene through Robinsons eyes  and hear the anthem through his ears  we encounter an altogether different story. Writing a quarter of a century after the 1947 World Series, Robinson observed, I cannot stand and sing the anthem. I cannot salute the flag; I know that I am a Black man in a white world. In 1972, in 1947, at my birth in 1919, I know that I never had it made.

title: How to Identify Flawed Research Before It Becomes Dangerous
description: Researchers have responded to the challenge of the coronavirus with a commitment to speed and cooperation, featuring the rapid sharing of preliminary findings through preprints, scientific manuscripts that have not yet undergone formal peer review.

title: Will Clean Energy Projects Face Troubles That Have Bedeviled Pipelines?
description: This month, environmentalists celebrated setbacks to three major oil and gas pipelines, nearly a decade after the protests against the Keystone XL pipeline began. Yet what goes around can come around. Legal strategies that have derailed pipelines can also be turned against clean energy projects urgently needed to combat climate change.

title: Less Optimistic and More Cautious: Top C.E.O.s Fret as Virus Cases Rise
description: With coronavirus cases around the country on the rise and states rolling back their reopening plans, many of the nation's top business leaders are steeling themselves for a period of prolonged economic disruption and the prospect of a slow, halting recovery.

title: How to Reopen the Economy Without Killing Teachers and Parents
description: The debate about reopening schools seems to pit parents and their employers against teachers. But there is actually a solution that would let grown-ups go back to work, educate kids and keep everyone safe at the same time.

title: A Timely Case on Police Violence at the Supreme Court
description: Early on a summer morning in Albuquerque in 2014, two state police officers in dark tactical gear arrived at a housing complex to serve an arrest warrant. In the parking lot, they came upon Roxanne Torres, sitting in her car with the engine running.

title: With a U.N. Veto, Russia and China Add to Syrias Misery
description: Earlier this month in the United Nations Security Council, the world saw a preview of what Russian and Chinese global leadership looks like: a world order where the most vulnerable suffer for the political gains of those at the top.

title: The Link Between Parkinsons Disease and Toxic Chemicals
description: Michael Richard Clifford, a 66-year-old retired astronaut living in Cary, N.C., learned before his third spaceflight that he had Parkinsons disease. He was only 44 and in excellent health at the time, and had no family history of this disabling neurological disorder.

title: Downsizing From a Two-Bedroom to a Studio
description: Cooped up at home these last four months, many New Yorkers have found themselves longing for larger apartments. But Kayla Oberlin and her partner Inbar Madar, who moved from a two-bedroom in Bushwick to a studio apartment in a Williamsburg high-rise late last fall, are not among them.

title: Would the Prophet Muhammad Convert Hagia Sophia?
description: The recent decision by the Turkish government to reconvert the majestic Hagia Sophia, which was once the worlds greatest cathedral, from a museum back to a mosque has been bad news for Christians around the world. They include Pope Francis, who said he was pained by the move, and the spiritual leader of Eastern Christianity, Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew, who said he was saddened and shaken. When contrasted with the joy of Turkeys conservative Muslims, all this may seem like a new episode in an old story: Islam vs. Christianity.

title: The Pandemic Has Pushed Aside City Planning Rules. But to Whose Benefit?
description: One month into the coronavirus crisis this spring, Oakland, Calif., began to restrict car traffic on some streets  ultimately on 21 miles of them  to create outdoor space for residents who suddenly had nowhere else to go.

title: Building Accessibility Into America, Literally
description: The Capitol Crawl, it came to be called. In March 1990, several dozen activists, cheered on by supporters, left their canes and wheelchairs and pulled themselves up the steep stone steps of the United States Capitol.

title: A Rush to Use Black Art Leaves the Artists Feeling Used
description: The streets of New York were crowded with protesters when Shantell Martin received an email from an ad agency last month.

title: N.Y.C. Enters Phase 4, but Restaurants and Bars Are Left Behind
description: For the 25,000 restaurants and bars in New York City, Monday was supposed to be a day of celebration  the turning point when the city would enter Phase 4, the final phase of reopening after the coronavirus outbreak.

title: If Its Here, Its Here: Americas Retirees Confront the Virus in Florida
description: THE VILLAGES, Fla.  For months, many of the residents at one of Americas biggest retirement communities went about their lives as if the coronavirus barely existed. They played bridge. They held dances. They went to house parties in souped-up golf carts that looked like miniature Jaguars and Rolls-Royces.

title: Yankee Stadium Area Is Hurting, and Baseballs Return Wont Help
description: By this point in a normal summer, the New York Yankees would have drawn more than 1.8 million fans to their palatial stadium in the South Bronx. On game days, the bars and souvenir shops around the ballpark would be overflowing with customers.

title: The Black Sanitation Workers Who Are Saying, I Am a Man
description: All labor has dignity, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. told striking sanitation workers in Memphis more than 50 years ago.

title: As Trump Slumps, Republican Donors Look to Save the Senate
description: Follow our live coverage of the 2020 election between Joe Biden and President Trump.

title: Without Music, Tanglewood Is Empty, Eerie and Beautiful
description: LENOX, Mass.  Andr Bernard was three months old when he attended his first concert at Tanglewood: Benny Goodman playing Mozarts Clarinet Concerto, in 1956. For nearly every one of the next 63 years, he has made a pilgrimage to the lush, sprawling lawn of this summer music mecca here in the Berkshires.

title: A Glimpse Inside the Workshops of the Worlds Finest Panama Hat Makers
description: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series  The World Through a Lens  in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planets most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Roff Smith shares a collection of photographs from the workshops of hat artisans in Ecuador.

title: With Tourists Gone, Bali Workers Return to Farms and Fishing
description: LALANGLINGGAH VILLAGE, Indonesia  Ni Nyoman Ayu Sutaryani, a mother of three, made a steady living for two decades working as a masseuse and yoga instructor at Balis luxury hotels and spas. Now at 37 she finds herself back on the farm of her childhood village here, standing precariously at the top of a tall bamboo ladder, picking cloves.

title: Death and Testing
description: President Trump gave a confrontational interview to Chris Wallace of Fox News yesterday that included numerous untruths about the coronavirus. Trump claimed that the United States had the lowest death rate in the world; that new cases were surging here mostly because of the large number of tests; and that his virus response had saved millions of lives.

title: REIs response to virus cases angers employees.
description: The outdoor equipment co-op REI is facing a backlash over its handling of coronavirus cases among its employees, with some nervous workers pushing for more transparency as stores reopen.

title: N.F.L. Players Say #WeWantToPlay but Question Training Camp Safety
description: The N.F.L. plays football in rainstorms, blizzards and blazing heat. Now, the league wants to play in a pandemic.

title: What Are Federal Agents Doing in Portland?
description: Armed federal agents are patrolling the streets of Portland against the wishes of local leaders, and the president refuses to guarantee that he wont contest the official results of the election. Its Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.

title: Delta says passengers who dont wear masks face a health screening.
description: Delta Air Lines said it would require passengers unable to wear face masks because of health conditions to undergo a medical clearance at the airport before boarding  or the passengers should reconsider travel altogether.

title: C.E.O.s Say Its a Grind
description: Hong Kong, considered an exemplar of coronavirus containment, is seeing a surge in infections  a warning for the rest of the world. And a new study in South Korea suggests that children older than 10 can spread the virus as readily as adults, which could complicate school reopenings. More on that below. title: I Have to Go in and Decolonize: Europes Black Theater Makers Discuss the Scene
description: LONDON  This summer, a coalition of American theater artists issued a statement, We See You, White American Theater, calling for an overhaul of the countrys theater landscape. There should be term limits on theater industry leaders to improve representation, it said, and at least half of casts and creative teams should be people of color.

title: A Retelling of American History  in Neon
description: In this new series, The Artists, an installment of which will publish every day this week and regularly thereafter, T will highlight a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist, putting the work into context. First up is a piece by Maya Stovall, who is best known for her dance performances in public spaces, as documented in her Liquor Store Theater video series, which will screen this summer as part of the citywide digital-art exhibition Art Mile Detroit.

title: Top Democrats Send Letter on Possible Foreign Meddling in November Election
description: [Follow the DNC Live: Bidens speech, schedule, start time, streaming and more.]

title: In a Time of Crisis, Is Art Essential?
description: For the last two summers, T has published an online art issue in which we celebrate artistic freedom in the face of overwhelming odds. Traditionally, these odds have revolved around an international supply chain largely fueled by greed: The small but powerful ecosystem that we refer to as the art world has always exploited artists to protect its profit margins.

title: American Fashion Nominates the Designers of the Year. They Really Make You Think.
description: When the coronavirus prompted the Council of Fashion Designers of America to postpone the 2020 CFDA Fashion Awards, the annual Oscars of the Fashion World (industry prom) originally scheduled for June 8, it seemed like another glittering evening of voyeurism and celebration had fallen to the pandemic.

title: Once a Model City, Hong Kong Grapples With a New Coronavirus Wave
description: Hong Kong once seemed like a model for how to control the coronavirus. Schools were open. Restaurants and malls buzzed with crowds. Buses and trains operated as usual, with residents dutifully wearing face masks on board.

title: What You Get for $2.4 Million in California
description: A Tudor Revival house in Los Angeles, a contemporary home in Menlo Park and a Craftsman-style bungalow in Carpinteria.

title: $2.4 Million Homes in California
description: This house, in the Hollywood Dell section of the Hollywood Hills, was built in the Tudor Revival style popular in 1920s Los Angeles. The actor David Niven, who once lived here, wrote about it in his memoir, The Moons a Balloon.

title: H.I.V. Survivors Confront Painful Memories and New Risks in Pandemic
description: Good morning.

title: A Place Where Everybody Can Shop Is Closing Its Doors
description: PARIS  Tati is a ghost of what it once was, and soon it wont even be that. Shelves that were crammed with dish-scrubbers and brassieres for $1.50 and plaster figurines of smiling bunnies are now bare. Exits are still numbered  how else to find your way out through the crowds  but the aisles are empty. There are no crowds.

title: Maryland Special Election Results: Seventh Congressional District
Ohio Primary Election Results: First Congressional District
Ohio Primary Election Results: 10th Congressional District
Ohio Primary Election Results: 12th Congressional District
Ohio Primary Election Results: Second Congressional District
Ohio Primary Election Results: Ninth Congressional District
Ohio Primary Election Results: 16th Congressional District
Ohio Primary Election Results: 14th Congressional District
Ohio Primary Election Results: Fifth Congressional District
Ohio Primary Election Results: Eighth Congressional District
Ohio Primary Election Results: Sixth Congressional District
Ohio Primary Election Results: Fourth Congressional District
Ohio Primary Election Results: 15th Congressional District
Ohio Primary Election Results: 11th Congressional District
Ohio Primary Election Results: 13th Congressional District
The Japanese-American Sculptor Who, Despite Persecution, Made Her Mark
description: IN 2009, THE New York City auction house Christies received an unsolicited query: A woman named Addie Lanier had a painting by Josef Albers, the midcentury abstract artist who pioneered modern arts education. Could Christies help her sell it? It wasnt uncommon for a major auction house like Christies to get cold calls. News generated by large sales can create curiosity and spark interest; people often approach auction houses in the hope of confirming that they have been sitting on priceless works of art. Jonathan Laib  then a senior vice president and senior specialist of postwar and contemporary art at Christies  was excited to hear of an Albers.

title: Heres the business news to watch this week.
description: More than 90 companies listed on the S&P 500 report their latest earnings this week. So far, 73 percent of blue-chip companies that have released second-quarter results beat analyst expectations, according to FactSet. Can they keep it up?

title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Good morning. My pal Ricky turned me on to a breakfast sandwich of the sort I used to order in delis or bodegas or bagel shops, back when I frequented them daily: toasted sesame bagel with butter and Swiss cheese. Thats a great sandwich: simple, salty, vaguely sweet, with a tang from the cheese. If you ask for it with ham, stipulate one slice only. Any more than that, and its a lunch sandwich, better consumed with mayonnaise and mustard, sliced pickles, a side of chips.

title: U.K. Suspends Extradition Treaty With Hong Kong Over Security Law
description: LONDON  In an escalation of tensions with China, Britain on Monday suspended an extradition treaty with Hong Kong to protest a new security law that gives China sweeping powers and is seen by critics as imperiling basic freedoms in the former British colony.

title: Total Bellas Refuse to Be Knocked Out by Quarantine
description: When Nikki and Brie Bella, twin sisters who are also reality stars and recently retired WWE champions, found out they were both pregnant last November, they were most excited about the pizookies.

title: From Good Wine, a Direct Path to the Wonders of Nature
description: Last year a friend asked me a question I had never considered before: Over the many years I had been writing about wine, what was the greatest thing this job had given me?

title: There Are Wasps in the Yard. Youd Better Get to Know Them.
description: Wasps get a bad rap. And sometimes, they deserve it. Bumblebees dont swarm your barbecue the moment you pour the lemonade. Butterflies wont nest by the hundreds in your rafters, then sting you for the crime of walking by.

title: Anti-Feminist Lawyer Is Suspect in Killing of Son of Federal Judge in N.J.
description: Roy Den Hollander was a self-described anti-feminist lawyer who flooded the courts with seemingly frivolous lawsuits that sought to eliminate womens studies programs and prohibit nightclubs from holding ladies nights.

title: Global Warming Is Driving Polar Bears Toward Extinction, Researchers Say
description: Polar bears could become nearly extinct by the end of the century as a result of shrinking sea ice in the Arctic if global warming continues unabated, scientists said Monday.

title: Georgia Democrats Choose Nikema Williams to Fill John Lewiss Seat in Congress
description: ATLANTA  Nikema Williams, a state senator from Atlanta, emerged from a conclave of Georgia Democratic officials on Monday as the appointed successor to Representative John Lewis, taking his place on the November ballot and very likely inheriting the seat he occupied in Congress for 17 terms.

title: For Some Artists, Election Season Means Enough of Trump
description: Voters heading to the polls this election season in battleground states like Michigan and Pennsylvania may find themselves facing billboards, projections and even cornfield cutouts designed by the countrys leading artists with a simple refrain: Enough is enough.

title: In 5 Minutes, You Can Have a (Slightly) Tidier Bedroom
description: Books, jewelry, chargers, assorted junk ... lets take a few minutes to make your nightstand a place of zen.

title: New Treatment for Covid-19 Shows Promise, but Scientists Urge Caution
description: LONDON  A British drug company said Monday that an inhaled form of a commonly used medicine could slash the odds of Covid-19 patients becoming severely ill, a sliver of good news in the race to find treatments that was met by scientists with equal measures of caution and cheer.

title: Big Polling Leads Tend to Erode. Is Bidens Edge Different?
description: Joe Bidens commanding advantage in the race for the White House shows no sign of abating. He led by 15 percentage points in an ABC News/Washington Post survey of registered voters on Sunday, and he has held a nearly double-digit lead in an average of polls for more than a month.

title: Marcella Hazans Tomato Sauce Trilogy
description: Follow NYT Food on Twitter and NYT Cooking on Instagram, Facebook, YouTube and Pinterest. Get regular updates from NYT Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.

title: How Porky Pig Works From Home
description: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

title: Why a Medical Interpreter Felt Disposable Amid Covid-19
description: Marta Rodriguez, a medical interpreter

title: Video Shows Police Beating Portland Protester
description: Video shows federal officers beating a Navy veteran at protests in Portland, Ore.

title: Google Promises Privacy With Virus App but Can Still Collect Location Data
description: When Google and Apple announced plans in April for free software to help alert people of their possible exposure to the coronavirus, the companies promoted it as privacy preserving and said it would not track users locations. Encouraged by those guarantees, Germany, Switzerland and other countries used the code to develop national virus alert apps that have been downloaded more than 20 million times.

title: Hotels Nix Mints and Breakfast Buffets. Hand Sanitizer, Anyone?
description: Those hotel amenities you took for granted, like throw pillows, turndown service and free coffee in the lobby? Theyre gone. Housekeeping is by request or eliminated during your stay. And dont even think of finding a self-serve breakfast buffet.

title: The Federal Crackdown on Portland Protesters
description: To the Editor:

title: Juice WRLDs Legends Never Die Earns the Years Biggest Debut
description: Juice WRLD, the rapper and singer from Chicago who died in December at age 21, has landed the biggest opening week of the year so far with a posthumous release, Legends Never Die.

title: A Navy Veteran Had a Question for the Feds in Portland. They Beat Him in Response.
description: Christopher J. David had largely ignored the protests in downtown Portland, Ore., but when he saw videos of unidentified federal agents grabbing protesters off the street and throwing them into rented minivans, he felt compelled to act.

title: Trump Announces He Will Resume Virus Daily Briefings
description: On Monday, President Trump announced he would begin daily virus briefings again after halting them in April.

title: Trump Says He Aced a Cognitive Test. What Does That Really Mean?
description: In recent interviews, President Trump has been boasting about a cognitive test that he took recently and aced. Its not the first time  he made similar remarks in January 2018. But he once again has not said what test he took, or what his score was, making it difficult to know what to make of his claims.

title: At Least 60 Migrants Killed in Turkish Boat Disaster
description: ISTANBUL  Turkish rescue teams have retrieved the bodies of 60 migrants after their boat sank in a lake in the east of the country, Turkish media reported on Monday, in one of the worst disasters involving migrants in Turkey in recent years.

title: Jailed Soccer Official Contracts Coronavirus in Florida Prison
description: Juan ngel Napout, a former vice president of soccers governing body FIFA serving a nine-year sentence for corruption, has tested positive for the coronavirus inside a Miami federal prison. The positive result came days after a federal judge denied his appeal for compassionate release.

title: Its a Risk for Everybody: Why a Jazz Pianist Chose to Perform
description: On Saturday, four months and 10 days since his last public performance, the Grammy-winning jazz pianist Bill Charlap came out to play.

title: On-Demand Webinar: Give Students a Voice by Incorporating Contests in Your Curriculum
description: For 11 years now, The Learning Network has been running contests that offer students a chance to share their ideas and opinions with the world. Through photography and editorials or personal narratives and podcasts, our contests give students a voice and the opportunity to write for an authentic audience. Each year tens of thousands of students participate.

title: Trumps Views on Covid Tests and Vaccines
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheldon Silver, Former N.Y. Assembly Speaker, Will Finally Go to Prison
description: Sheldon Silver, the once dominant New York State Assembly speaker who for nearly five years fended off prison after being convicted twice on corruption charges, lost a final bid for freedom on Monday when he was sentenced to 78 months in prison.

title: TV Reporter Dies After Accident Involving Revel Scooter
description: A local television journalist died over the weekend, the police said, after she fell from a scooter that had been rented from Revel, a moped-sharing company whose Vespa-style vehicles have become a familiar sight on the streets of Brooklyn and Queens.

title: Baseball in Middle America: Fans Are In, Autographs Are Out
description: FARGO, N.D.  Forget about everything else for a moment and take a look at this:

title: I Am Stuck Between Two Lives During This Pandemic
For Women in Afghan Security Forces, a Daily Battle
description: KHOST, Afghanistan  Motivated, educated and fresh from finishing police academy in Turkey, Second Lt. Zala Zazai had stellar qualifications for the job she took in eastern Afghanistan in June. It all mattered little once she started.

title: India Outbreak, Hong Kong, Bali Economy: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: 3 Friends Massacred During Florida Fishing Trip, Police Say
description: On a dirt road, near cow pastures, orange groves and lakes, a Florida sheriff said he encountered one of the worst crime scenes in his career last week: Three close friends appeared to have been beaten and shot to death during a nighttime catfishing trip.
